Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [400]. No formal currency was present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ suspected unknown ♥ The ritual specialists were provided with a meal (see above). Thomas Cressy: A meal may not count as property/valuable items
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [401]. The patient may be seriously ill, but this is not a result of the ritual itself (see above).
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [402].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [403].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [404].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [405].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ War Dance ♥ The reservation-period data sheet (see UsIroqL for reference) is coded for the Tenth-Day Funerary Feast as imported from the Ritual Database [406]. The ethnography seems to imply that this ritual was introduced by the Handsome Lake religion. We have therefore decided to code for a different set of rituals for the pre-reservation period. 'With the Iroquois, as with the red race at large, dancing was not only regarded as a thanksgiving ceremonial, in itself acceptable to the Great Spirit, but they were taught to consider it a divine art, designed by Hä-wen-ne[unknown] -yu for their pleasure, as well as for his worship. It was cherished as one of the most suitable modes of social intercourse between the sexes, but more especially as the great instrumentality for arousing patriotic excitement, and for keeping alive the spirit of the nation. The popular enthusiasm broke forth in this form, and was nourished and stimulated by this powerful agency. These dances sprang, as it were, a living reflection from the Indian mind. With their wild music of songs and rattles, their diversities of step and attitude, their graces of motion, and their spirit-stirring associations, [Page 250] they contain within themselves both a picture and a realization of Indian life. The first stir of feeling of which the Indian youth was conscious was enkindled by the dance; the first impulse of patriotism, the earliest dreams of ambition were awakened by their inspiring influences. In their patriotic, religious and social dances, into which classes they are properly divisible, resided the soul of Indian life. It was more in the nature of a spell upon the people than of a rational guiding spirit. It bound them down to trivial things, but it bound them together; it stimulated them to deeds of frenzy, but it fed the flame of patriotism.' [407] 'The Feather dance and the War dance were the two great performances of the Iroquois. One had a religious, and the other a patriotic character. Both were costume dances. They were performed by a select band, ranging from fifteen to twenty-five, who were distinguished for their powers of endurance, activity and spirit.' [408]//'One was of original invention, the other imported; one was of a strictly religious character, and the other of a patriotic; but both were equally effective to arouse the enthusiasm of the people. All things considered, however, the last of the two, the War dance, Wä-sä[unknown] -seh, was the favorite. It was the mode of enlistment for a perilous expedition, the dance which preceded the departure of the band, and with which [Page 258] they celebrated their return. It was the dance at the ceremony of raising up sachems, at the adoption of a captive, at the entertainment of a guest, the first dance taught to the young. It was not of Iroquois origin, but was adopted from the Sioux, as its name imports, reaching back through them to a remote antiquity. The characteristic feature of this dance is to be found in the speeches which were made by those surrounding the band of dancers between each tune, or at each break in the dance. From this source the people derived as much entertainment as they did excitement from the performance itself. It was the only dance in which speeches and replies were appropriate, or ever introduced; and in this particular it was a novelty, leading oftentimes to the highest amusement. By these speeches, which both relieved the performers and diverted the people, the dance was lengthened out to two and even three hours, before the spirits of the company were expended.' [409]//'The War dance was usually performed in the evening. It was only brought out on prominent occasions, or at domestic councils of unusual interest. Fifteen made a full company, but oftentimes twenty-five and even thirty participated. After the business of the day was disposed of, and the dusk of evening had crept in, [Page 259] preparations began for the dance. The people gathered within the council-house, usually in increased numbers, because of this expected entertainment, and arranging themselves in favorable positions, they quietly awaited the approach of the dancers. The arrangements were made, including the selection of the number, the appointment of the leader, and of the singers of the war-songs, by the keepers of the faith. In an adjacent lodge, the band assembled to array themselves in their costumes, and to paint and decorate their persons for the occasion. The war-whoop ever and anon broke in upon the stillness of the evening, indicating to the listening and expectant throng within the council-house, that their preparations were progressing to a completion. A keeper of the faith, in the mean time, occupied the attention of the people with a brief speech upon the nature and objects of this dance. Presently, a nearer war-whoop ringing through the air, announced that the band were approaching. Preceded by their leader, and marching in file to the beat of the drum, they drew near to the council-house. As they came up, the crowd gave way, the leader crossed the threshold, followed quickly by his feathered band, and immediately opened the dance. In an instant they grouped themselves within a circular area, standing thick together, the singers commenced the war-song, the drums beat time, and the dancers made the floor resound with their stirring feet. After a moment the song ceased, and with it the dance; the band walking around a common centre to the beat of the drum at half time. Another song soon commenced, the drums quickened their time, and the dance was resumed. In [Page 260] the middle of the song there was a change in the music, accompanied with a slight cessation of the dance, after which it became more animated than before, until the song ended, and the band again walked to the beat of the drum. Each tune or war-song lasted about two minutes, and the interval between them was about as long. These songs were usually recited by four singers, using two drums of the kind represented in the figure, to mark time, and as an accompaniment. The drums beat time about twice in a second, the voices of the singers keeping pace, thus making a rapid and strongly accented species of music.' [410]//'It would be difficult, if not impossible, to describe the step, except generally. With the whites, the dancing is entirely upon the toe of the foot, with rapid changes of position, and but slight changes of attitude. But with the Iroquois, it was chiefly upon the heel, with slow changes of position, and rapid changes of attitude. The heel is raised and brought down with great quickness and force, by muscular strength, to keep time with the beat of the drum, to make a resounding noise by the concussion, and at the same time to shake the knee-rattles, which contributed materially to the “pomp and circumstance” of the dance. In the War dance, the attitudes were those of [Page 261] the violent passions, and consequently were not graceful. At the same instant of time, in a group of dancers, one might be seen in the attitude of attack, another of defence; one in the act of drawing the bow, another of striking with the war-club; some in the act of throwing the tomahawk, some of listening, or of watching an opportunity, and others of striking the foe. These violent motions of the body, while they, perhaps, increased the spirit and animation of the dance, led to disagreeable distortions of the countenance, as well as to uncouth attitudes. But, at the same time, the striking costumes of the dancers, their erect forms at certain stages of the figure, their suppleness and activity, the wild music, the rattle of the dance, together with the excitable and excited throng around them, made up a scene of no common interest.' [411]//'In this dance, the war-whoop and the response always preceded each song. It was given by the leader, and answered by the band. A description of this terrific outbreak of human voices is scarcely possible. It was a prolonged sound upon a high note, with a decadence near the end, followed by an abrupt and explosive conclusion, in which the voice was raised again to the original pitch. The whole band responded in a united scream upon the same key with which the leader concluded, and at the same instant.' [412]//'In this celebrated dance, therefore, which has doubtless been used for centuries, and been performed throughout the whole area of the American republic, we find this simple succession of acts: the war-whoop and responses, the simultaneous commencement of the war-song and the dance, the slight cessation at the middle of the tune, with a change in the music, the renewal of the dance with redoubled animation, and the final conclusion of the war-song in perhaps less than two minutes from its commencement; and lastly, the walk at the beat of the drum around a central point for about two minutes, until the war-whoop again sounded, and another war-song was introduced. This round was continued until the spirit of the dancers began to flag, and the desires of the people had been reasonably gratified. Without any speeches between the tunes to relieve the band, it usually lasted about an hour; but with speeches, it often continued for three hours with unabated animation. Any one present was at liberty to make a speech at any stage of the dance. His desire was manifested by a rap. At the sound the dance ceased, or, if finished, and the band were walking, they were required to stop, and all present, as well as the music, to be silent. The only condition affixed to the right of making a speech, was that of bestowing a present at its close upon the dancers, or upon the one to whom it was addressed. After the speech was concluded, and the present delivered, the war-whoop and responses were again sounded, the drums beat, the [Page 263] song and the dance commenced, and were ended as before. Then followed another speech, and still others, alternating with the songs, or suspending the dance at the moment of its highest animation, at the pleasure of the speaker. In this manner the War dance was continued until the spirit of enjoyment began to subside, when the final war-whoop put an end to the dance, and the band retired.' [413]//Oratory was also present: 'These speeches were often pleasantries between individuals, or strictures upon each other's foibles, or earnest exhortations, or perchance patriotic ebullitions of feeling, according to the fancy of the person and of the moment. Some of them were received with rounds of applause, some with jeers, and others with seriousness and deference. They usually lasted but two or three minutes. The Indian has a keen appreciation of wit, and is fond of both jest and repartee, as well as of ridicule.' [414]//The content of the speeches given refers to a reservation-period context, but we have assumed that earlier manifestations of the ceremony were broadly comparable.
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ seasonally ♥ Based on the following quote, it seems likely that this dance was performed less often than monthly, but more often than yearly. 'It was the mode of enlistment for a perilous expedition, the dance which preceded the departure of the band, and with which they celebrated their return. It was the dance at the ceremony of raising up sachems, at the adoption of a captive, at the entertainment of a guest, the first dance taught to the young.' [415] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ The War Dance was performed at the departure and return of raiding parties and on some other special occasions (see above). We have therefore assumed that this dance was performed more than once per generation, but less often than monthly. We have assumed that the frequency was reduced for performers, as not everyone would perform on every occasion. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ seasonally ♥ Based on the following quote, it seems likely that this dance was performed less often than monthly, but more often than yearly. 'It was the mode of enlistment for a perilous expedition, the dance which preceded the departure of the band, and with which they celebrated their return. It was the dance at the ceremony of raising up sachems, at the adoption of a captive, at the entertainment of a guest, the first dance taught to the young.' [416] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours Inferred from the fact that the ceremony was of relatively short duration and was terminated once the performers were exhausted: 'In this manner the War dance was continued until the spirit of enjoyment began to subside, when the final war-whoop put an end to the dance, and the band retired.' [417] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ [15-30] ♥ in absolute numbers. 'Fifteen made a full company, but oftentimes twenty-five and even thirty participated.' [418] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ keepers of the faith. There were both male and female Keepers of the Faith: 'Full time religious specialists were absent, however, there were part-time male and female specialists known as Keepers of the Faith whose primary responsibilities were to arrange and conduct the main religious ceremonies. Keepers of the Faith were appointed by matrisib elders and were accorded considerable prestige.' [419]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ substantial minority ♥ all adult males. The dance was performed by warriors: 'It was the mode of enlistment for a perilous expedition, the dance which preceded the departure of the band, and with which they celebrated their return. It was the dance at the ceremony of raising up sachems, at the adoption of a captive, at the entertainment of a guest, the first dance taught to the young.' [420]. Because there was no 'warrior class' in Iroquois society, it seems reasonable to infer that all adult males could participate. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ Inferred from the popularity of this dance [421]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
Dysphoric elements

♠ fear ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [424].
♠ humiliation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [425].
♠ disgust ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [426].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [427].
♠ pain ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [428].
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [429].
♠ risk of death ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [430].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [431].
♠ alcohol ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [432].
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ Dancers were given tobacco by audience members (see above), but it appears that this was intended as a gift and that the tobacco was not consumed on the spot. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ sex ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [433].
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ The War Dance was an elaborate performance made up of drumming, songs, and rhythmic movement which was synchronized at times [434]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ present ♥ The War Dance was an elaborate performance made up of drumming, songs, and rhythmic movement which was synchronized at times [435]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ The War Dance was an elaborate performance made up of drumming, songs, and rhythmic movement which was synchronized at times [436]. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ To this day, a well-conducted War dance is the highest entertainment known among the Iroquois.' [437] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred present ♥ Based on the following quote, the War Dance appears to be a very good example of a ritual whose participants were subsequently honour-bound to act together. 'Dressed in full costume, the war-chief who proposed to solicit volunteers and conduct the expedition, went through the village sounding the war-whoop to announce his intentions; after which he went to the war-post, Gä-on-dot[unknown], and having struck into it his red tomahawk, he commenced the war-dance. A group gathered around him, and as their martial ardor was aroused by the dance, they enlisted, one after the other, by joining in its performance. In this manner a company was soon formed; the matrons of the village prepared their subsistence while the dance was performing; and at its close, while they were yet fired with enthusiasm for the enterprise, they immediately left the village, and turned their footsteps towards the country of the enemy. If the movement was simultaneous in several villages, these parties joined each other on their march, but each band continued under the direction of its own war-chief." [438] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [439]. Oratory was present, but we have found no evidence of honour codes or oath taking (see above). NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ inferred present ♥ Based on the following quote, the War Dance appears to be a very good example of a ritual whose participants were subsequently honour-bound to support each other in war. 'Dressed in full costume, the war-chief who proposed to solicit volunteers and conduct the expedition, went through the village sounding the war-whoop to announce his intentions; after which he went to the war-post, Gä-on-dot[unknown], and having struck into it his red tomahawk, he commenced the war-dance. A group gathered around him, and as their martial ardor was aroused by the dance, they enlisted, one after the other, by joining in its performance. In this manner a company was soon formed; the matrons of the village prepared their subsistence while the dance was performing; and at its close, while they were yet fired with enthusiasm for the enterprise, they immediately left the village, and turned their footsteps towards the country of the enemy. If the movement was simultaneous in several villages, these parties joined each other on their march, but each band continued under the direction of its own war-chief." [440] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ inferred present ♥ Based on the following quote, the War Dance appears to be a very good example of a ritual whose participants were subsequently honour-bound to support each other in war. 'Dressed in full costume, the war-chief who proposed to solicit volunteers and conduct the expedition, went through the village sounding the war-whoop to announce his intentions; after which he went to the war-post, Gä-on-dot[unknown], and having struck into it his red tomahawk, he commenced the war-dance. A group gathered around him, and as their martial ardor was aroused by the dance, they enlisted, one after the other, by joining in its performance. In this manner a company was soon formed; the matrons of the village prepared their subsistence while the dance was performing; and at its close, while they were yet fired with enthusiasm for the enterprise, they immediately left the village, and turned their footsteps towards the country of the enemy. If the movement was simultaneous in several villages, these parties joined each other on their march, but each band continued under the direction of its own war-chief." [441] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ inferred present ♥ Eva: the warriors going into battle were probably from related lineages, with habitual marriage exchange
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ Eva: Concerns with correct performance had probably more to do with efficacy than with liturgy.
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ present ♥ 'A keeper of the faith, in the mean time, occupied the attention of the people with a brief speech upon the nature and objects of this dance.' [442] NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [443]. No formal currency was present prior to colonization. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Audience members rewarded performers with tobacco, and those who had helped with the preparation of the ceremony also received a small reward (see above). We have assumed that in the pre-reservation period, these small gifts may have consisted of food and tobacco rather than money. NOTE: Our main source dates to the nineteenth century. Thomas Cressy: Surely the participants receiving a gift from the audience is not a cost of participating? Changed from present to 'suspected unknown'
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [444].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [445].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [446].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [447].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Inferred from the fact that this is not mentioned in Morgan's account of the nineteenth-century version of this ritual [448].
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Funeral ♥ 'On the morning of the funeral the corpse is provided with a “lunch” consisting of corn bread 2 inches in diameter, which has been baked in ashes (“the dead people's way”). At Sour Springs the body is carried in and out of the longhouse through the women's door, while at Lower Cayuga and Seneca the east door is used for the entrance and the west for the exit. In all cases the foot end of the coffin is carried in first to simulate “walking” into the Longhouse, as if the person were “still with us.” The coffin is opened and placed in the center of the house on the singers' benches, the head westward and the feet eastward. Seating for a funeral is according to sex. A second condolence address is given by the speaker who had consoled the bereaved at home earlier. He says that perhaps some relatives had not heard the words expressed at the house, and therefore he condoles them again. Furthermore, he condoles the entire moiety of the bereaved, specifying as usual each of the ranks in the hierarchy. Then, the moiety of the deceased replies briefly in kind, avowing that the loss undoubtedly affected not them alone but also the condoling side. The speaker then announces that the people may now have a last look at the departed relative. All the speeches are phrased in such a way as to indicate that the deceased is still among the people, passing through the Longhouse a final time on his way to heaven. Going up to the coffin for a last look is considered extremely important, and orthodox members insist that the body must be brought into the Longhouse and must be visible. At Sour Springs the women circle the coffin counterclockwise first, followed by the men, and then followed by the family of the deceased, which is not separated by sex. After all have circled, the speaker announces that the coffin will be closed and the remains laid to rest. The coffin is carried out feet first, again as if the deceased were walking. Mourners then follow the coffin to the burial ground of the Longhouse, where the speaker delivers the last address. He indicates that now the departed has arrived at the final resting place and henceforth will be entrusted to the Creator. The mourners have done their duty as decreed by the Creator, and they should now release their hands from the dead. The coffin is lowered, again with the head to the west, and two shovels of earth are symbolically placed on the lowered coffin by a member of the moiety opposite to that of the deceased. Sometimes a single wreath from the family is added, and the mourners depart.' [449]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ This variable is contingent in part on population size and death rate.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [450], this ritual occurs 'once per generation'.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [451], this ritual occurs 'once per generation'.
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database [452], this ritual is coded as '1 to 6 hours/ long'.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 10 ♥ in absolute numbers According to the Ritual Database [453], 'Other small sub-group (<15)' participates in this ritual.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Thomas Cressy: a 'speaker' is mentioned in the ritual description but no information is provided on who this person is or who could become a 'speaker'.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database [454] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database [455] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database [456] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database [457] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database [458] is coded as 'absent'.
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [459].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing'. Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [460] as 'absent'. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database [461] is medium (3.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database [462] as 'absent'.
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [463], including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ death of a family member ♥ The pain coded in the Ritual Database [464] largely relates to the pain caused by the death of a loved one.
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database [465] is coded as 'absent'. No feast is mentioned.
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [466] variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [467].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [468].
♠ dancing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [469] variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ synchronous movement ♣ present ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison) Ritual Database [470] variable 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as 'present'.
♠ singing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database [471] variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'absent'.
♠ entertainment ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [472].
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [473].
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [474].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [475].
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [476].
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [477].
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [478].
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ absent ♥ No checks on orthodoxy are noted. 'Distribution of ritual exegesis' is coded in the Ritual Database [479] as 'Known by all competent participants' and the 'Dominant mode of acquisition of exegesis' is 'Learnt through verbal egalitaritarian transmission'.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formal currency is present.
♠ property/valuable items ♣ suspected unknown ♥ It is unclear who pays the funeral costs.
♠ health costs ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [480].
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [481].
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [482].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [483].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [484].
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)

Phase II Variables (polity-based)[edit]

Institutional Variables[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

♠ Editor ♣ ♥

eHRAF Archeology provides a general summary of the Late Eastern Woodland tradition (1300 B.P. - 500 B.P., precedes the historic period): 'The Late Woodland Tradition is widespread throughout the eastern woodlands from southern Canada to the Gulf Coast and from just west of the Mississippi river trench in the west to the shores of the Atlantic ocean to the east.' [485] 'Grit tempered, cordmarked ceramic cooking vessels in the northern region of the eastern woodlands, and ground shell-, limestone-, or grog-tempered vessels in the southern woodlands. A wide variety of projectile point forms were utilized during the Late Woodland period ranging from small, stemmed points early in the period, to notched and unnotched triangular forms after the introduction of the bow and arrow. House forms show a wide range of variation from the longhouse of the northeastern United States to the circular and ovoid forms of the western Great Lakes to rectangular, square, and ovoid forms of the southeastern United States.' [486] 'The Late Woodland tradition developed during the period of climatic amelioration commonly called the little climatic optimum (or medieval warm period) dating from 2100 to 750 B.P. Following 750 B.P. the climate became cooler as the affects of the "Little Ice Age" became more prominent.' [487] 'The topography of the eastern woodlands is highly diverse across the region. The Great Lakes and their associated low-lying coastal plains as well as the Mississippi river trench dominate the northwest portion of the area. The increasing relief of the Appalachian mountains characterizes the northeastern portion of the region, although the east coast is considered part of the Atlantic coastal plain. The southeast is dominated by the Atlantic and Gulf coastal plains, both of which provide diverse topography, which is however generally low lying. Finally, the southwestern portion of the eastern woodlands is relatively flat, with some relief being provided by the southwestern portion of the piedmont and Appalachian mountains. Mobile Late Woodland peoples appear to have taken advantage of both the major river floodplain environments and upland areas, practicing a seasonal round that maximized their landscape's potential for food production. More sedentary Late Woodland peoples chose river and lakeshore locations f or the majority of year.' [488] 'The eastern woodlands area can be divided into two major geologic provinces or subdivisions: (1) the stable interior craton, which includes the Canadian shield underlying the Great Lakes region and a broad area of relatively undeformed sediment covering the shield, which extends from the Great Lakes to the Gulf coast, and (2) the Appalachian orogenic belts. The Canadian shield is the oldest rock in the continent and contains huge deposits of iron and copper. The area to the south has been slightly deformed into a series of basins and domes including the Wisconsin dome, and the Michigan and Illinois basins. The sediments in these areas have consolidated into limestone, dolomite, shales, and sandstones and indicate that deposition took place in a variety of shallow marine and coastal plain environments. These formations contain abundant chert deposits. The Appalachian mountains are a classic fold and thrust belt that extends from Newfoundland to Alabama and was formed by continental collision in the beginning of the Early Paleozoic. The Appalachian mountains consist of four zones: the valley and ridge province, the Blue Ridge province, the piedmont province, and the coastal plain. Some areas in the mountains contain localized deposits of copper, iron, crystals, and other minerals. Glaciation occurring in four major pulses depressed the central shield and Great Lakes area, creating the Great Lakes as well as the Mississippi and Ohio River drainages. A veneer of glacial drift covers the northern portion of the eastern woodlands area, creating hummocky, rolling topography. The drift contains copper, cherts, jaspers, and taconite. The southern Mississippi trench and Gulf coastal plain are characterized by a lack of stone and mineral resources, but are rich in fertile bottomland soils, clay, and salt springs.' [489] 'Peoples of the Late Woodland tradition utilized a wide range of habitats throughout the eastern United States, including mixed conifer-hardwood forests, deciduous forests, forest-prairie mosaic, prairies, oak-pine forests, and the southeastern evergreen forests. Riverine and marshland environments were utilized heavily in the spring, summer, and early fall for their aquatic and closely related terrestrial resources. Upland forests and more sheltered locations seem to have been favored during the late fall and winter, apparently to take advantage of upland resources such as nut mast and grazing mammals.' [490] 'Late Woodland settlement systems varied tremendously temporally and spatially throughout the eastern woodlands. In the north, Late Woodland peoples appear to have led a more mobile lifestyle during the early portions of the Late Woodland period. This is indicated by a pattern of large villages commonly inhabited during the late spring and summer and a series of smaller open-air and cave/rock shelter habitations representing a fall and winter dispersion of regional populations. These early larger villages usually did not contain monumental architecture and are commonly associated with mortuary facilities such as mounds and/or ossuaries. After the introduction of maize, larger, more permanent villages were established and were occupied for the majority of the year. Late Woodland tradition settlement systems in the southern portions of the eastern woodlands followed patterns similar to those in the north, with the exception of the development of civic-ceremonial centers with plazas and monumental architecture, i ncluding platform mounds, at a comparatively early date.' [491] 'Early Late Woodland communities in the northern eastern woodlands were generally small, consisting of between 2-10 houses with little or no visible civic planning, although some groups tended to organize their houses around a central work area. In the later portion of the Late Woodland period in the north, there was a tendency for villages to become larger with more storage facilities. Single or multiple palisades commonly enclosed these villages. Southern Late Woodland communities exhibited a wide range of variation, but the larger villages that served as civic-ceremonial centers appear to have a fair degree of civic planning. Typically, the center of the village was demarcated as a plaza. Platform mounds, often constructed to align with solstices, surrounded three or four sides of the plaza.' [492] 'Late Woodland house types varied throughout the eastern woodlands. In the northern portion of the region, five different Late Woodland house forms have been identified. These include oval, circular, "keyhole", rectangular with rounded corners, and longhouses. Although the first four styles imply single, nuclear family dwellings, the construction of longhouses indicates larger, multifamily units.' [493] 'Most regions in the eastern woodlands experienced population growth during the Late Woodland period. This may have been caused in part by the increasing reliance on horticultural products and then ultimately by the adoption of maize by many Late Woodland groups. In general, Late Woodland peoples who practiced a balanced hunting/fishing and gathering lifestyle were healthy with males living on average to age 40 and women to age 35. With the adoption of maize, there was an increase in dental caries and other diseases associated with increasing population densities and a sedentary lifestyle.' [494] 'Early in the Eastern Late Woodland tradition, the vast majority of peoples living outside of the American Bottom (the area at the confluence of the Mississippi, Illinois, and the Missouri Rivers in west-central Illinois and east-central Missouri) were largely hunters and gatherers with only a small percentage of their diet obtained through horticultural activities. This changed through time as Middle Mississippian tradition societies developed in the southern regions of the eastern woodlands and maize became more prevalent throughout the continent. Toward the end of the Eastern Late Woodland tradition, maize became a staple in many, if not most, Late Woodland societies.' [495] 'Fruits, nuts, starchy and oily seeds, as well as various roots were gathered by most Late Woodland tradition people. Wild deer appears to have been the dominant source of animal protein for Late Woodland peoples, although a wide range of mammal, bird, fish, and shellfish resources were also exploited depending on the regional context.' [496] 'Prior to the adoption of maize and beans, cucurbits, gourds, and domesticated starchy and oily seed plants such as sunflower, sumpweed, chenopod, knotweed, may grass, and little barley were presumably grown in small garden plots.' [497] 'Eastern Late Woodland tradition industrial arts seem to have been fairly basic in that there was very little elaboration on the ceramic and stone-working technologies utilized in prior Woodland traditions. It appears that most items were manufactured by individual households for use and consumption by that household.' [498] 'Ceramic domestic cooking jars and chipped stone tools were the most commonly used utensils during the Late Woodland tradition. Ceramics in the northern portion of the eastern woodlands were commonly grit tempered, relatively thin-walled, and covered with cord marking, a result of the paddling phase of the paddle and anvil production process. Additional decoration appeared in the form of cord wrapped-object, single and multiple strand cord, and fabric impressions. Vessels were generally globular in shape with a simple constricted orifice although a number of rim forms were utilized, including the application of thin strips of clay around the exterior of the vessel rim to create a collar. Ceramic vessels in the southern part of the eastern woodlands were tempered with grog, grit, or crushed limestone or shell. Vessel forms were more complex, with the addition of specialized forms such as water bottles, salt pans, and effigy forms. Southern decoration techniques often involved incising and the use of simple and complicated stamps. The near-universal acceptance of the bow and arrow across the region led to the rapid replacement of small stemmed projectile points with notched and unnotched triangular points.' [499] 'In the northern portions of the eastern woodlands, the Late Woodland tradition saw the reduction of archaeologically visible personal or group affiliated ornamentation. In some instances, Late Woodland groups on the northern border of the Middle Mississippian frontier adopted some Middle Mississippian ornaments such as marine shell disc beads. The overall decline in the use of copper, obsidian, mica, and other exotic raw materials that characterizes this period in the north suggests that ornamentation did not play a significant role among northern peoples. Among southern Late Woodland peoples however, the use of shell beads in both the disk and barrel shapes, especially in mortuary settings, indicates that ornamentation remained a sign of status.' [500] 'The basic economic unit among Late Woodland peoples appears to have been the nuclear family, which was able to produce most, if not all, of the food and goods that it needed to survive. Some have suggested that changes in trade relations formed the impetus for change in the sociopolitical landscape of eastern North America from band-level society to more complex forms of organization such as tribes and chiefdoms. The argument revolves around the concept that changes in material culture from more elaborate in the Middle Woodland, to very plain in the Late Woodland, indicates that individual Late Woodland groups were interested in forming inter-regional ties that would be capable of creating buffers against social and environmental shortfalls. Should one group be under pressure from another group, or need food, then allied groups would be under obligation to lend support. The nature of the items being exchanged in most cases is unknown, but it is fairly clear that at least in the northern portion of the eastern woodlands, the items being exchanged are not exotic raw materials or prestige goods.' [501] 'There does not appear to be any evidence for craft specialization in the majority of Late Woodland societies in the eastern woodlands. This conclusion is based on the lack of any evidence for standardized production or specialized "workshop areas." Although some prestige items were being manufactured, individuals who did not pursue craft production on a full-time basis likely made these.' [502] 'There is no physical evidence of differential access or control of resources in the Late Woodland tradition. However, the ethnographic record is full of instances where lineages or households in middle-range societies have demonstrated unequal access and control of resources like arable land, food resources such as maple sugar bushes, and even knowledge regarding the sacred, craft production, and trade routes. It is highly probable that Late Woodland peoples demonstrated these types of differential access and control of resources.' [503] 'Political organization in Late Woodland societies varied considerably across the eastern woodlands. In the north, inter- and intra-community settlement patterns, as well as a reasonable continuity between prehistoric and historic groups, suggest that Late Woodland peoples organized themselves around either the household or lineage in either band or tribal (middle-range) level societies. In general, societies with these types of organization make social and political decisions based on group consensus. Certain individuals or lineages are usually awarded higher status than others are, but this status is not inherited and is usually earned on the basis of size of lineage, personal prowess, age, sex [sic], and gender. In the southern portion of the eastern woodlands, many Late Woodland groups appear to have been organized around similar levels of complexity. However, a number of societies also appear to have made the transition to more complex levels of organizations such as chiefdoms, without reliance on maize a griculture and with little archaeological evidence of inherited status other than the construction of monumental architecture. These societies are probably best viewed as simple chiefdoms.' [504] 'Evidence for the occurrence of violence in and between Late Woodland groups increases from the beginning of the Late Woodland period until contact with Euro-Americans or absorption by, and contact with, Middle Mississippian peoples throughout the region. Conflict has been viewed as a consequence of increasing population density and trends toward sedentism or as a response to invasive populations. Certainly by 1100 B.P. there are numerous examples of fortified sites, changes in settlement location selection to defensible positions, and increases in the number of individuals who show evidence of violent death. It is clear from the evidence that many sedentary or semi-sedentary groups were engaged in warfare and that conflict played a significant role on the sociopolitical landscape and in material culture patterns.' [505] 'There is almost no archaeological evidence to support any theories regarding the religious beliefs of Late Woodland peoples. Ethnographic sources for peoples in the northern woodlands may or may not be applicable to Late Woodland societies but suggest an animistic orientation to their belief systems. Peoples of the southern woodlands seem to have shared at least some of their beliefs with their descendents; however, the time depth involved precludes any comprehensive hypotheses regarding belief systems' [506] 'Analysis of certain burials from northern Late Woodland people, as well as ethnographic accounts, suggests that some individuals in each community were considered to be religious or spiritual leaders. These individuals are often buried with various specialized tools and ritual objects that are not common in other burials. In the ethnographic records, these individuals could be referred to as medicine men or women, or shamans.' [507] 'There is very little archaeological evidence to suggest any type of formal ritual ceremonies during the Late Woodland period in the eastern United States. However, some aspects of ceremonial life among Late Woodland people can be inferred from intracommunity architectural studies. In the northern woodlands, larger specialized structures were constructed and apparently maintained for public ceremonies. Smaller circular or ovoid structures, presumably "sweat lodges," were constructed for personal or small group use. Some archaeologists have argued that northern woodland mound groups formed the center of annual ceremonies designed to bring people together to bury their dead. In the southern woodlands, numerous villages are laid out with a central plaza area that intimates public ceremonies were conducted in these areas. Typically these civic-ceremonial centers also contain platform mounds that held structures that were either used as temples, or in some cases, as specialized mortuary facilities.' [508] 'Evidence for artistic expression in the Late Woodland is minimal. It is likely that Late Woodland peoples worked in a variety of media such as leather, feathers, bone, wood, and other nonpreserved substances. In the northern eastern woodlands, what evidence does survive of artistic expression comes largely in the form of decoration on ceramics, carved stone, incised bone, and some poorly preserved fragments of fabrics. It is clear from these lines of evidence that Late Woodland peoples were fond of naturalistic motifs and geometric designs. In addition to the above artistic expressions, people of the southern eastern woodlands also constructed elaborate effigy-shaped ceramic vessels, often using slips and paints to add a color dimension to their expression.' [509] 'A great deal of evidence has been uncovered regarding rituals associated with death and the afterlife. A variety of burial treatments were used throughout the eastern woodlands, including primary and secondary inhumations, in the flesh, cremated, in bundles, and in flexed and extended positions. In the northern eastern woodlands, mounds, some of which were constructed in the form of animal effigies, were used to house the remains of anywhere between 1-50 individuals. Typically, elaborate grave goods do not accompany these burials; in fact, often there are no goods at all. In some cases, the mounds were constructed with what appears to be ritual forethought, considerable care being taken to layer the mound fill with soils of various colors. Evidence in the southern woodlands suggests that individuals were prepared in mortuary-oriented structures on top of mounds and then removed to a separate burial area where specialized ceramic vessels were interred with the burials.' [510]

The Encyclopedia of Prehistory (Volume 6: North America) provides a general summary of the proto-Iroquois tradition (950-350 B.P., precedes the historic period): 'The lower Great Lakes basin from approxi-mately the middle of lake Erie eastward, in Ontario north of the lakes and in New York south of the lakes, with extensions into the major river valleys of the St. Lawrence river in Quebec, the Mohawk river in New York, and the Susquehanna river in Pennsylvania.' [511] 'Thin-walled, usually grit-tempered globular pots with necks and applied collars with incised decoration and castellations, punc- tations, and/or notches. Ceramic smoking pipes of several forms: elbow (early), trumpet (middle), and effigy (late). Isosceles-triangular projectile points of the Madison type. Finely carved bone and shell ornaments (see Ornaments below). Polished ground-stone celts for tree felling. Settlement patterns are typically villages consisting of clusters of longhouses surrounded by palisades sited on defensible locations. Ossuary burials are common in Ontario and western New York during the later phases.' [512] 'Iroquoian groups occupied the northern- most zone of viable maize horticulture in eastern North America, namely, those areas within the limits of the 120-day frostfree growing season. Iroquoian culture appeared with its maize horticulture in a lowland "wedge" within a region of Algonquian speakers during the Neo-Atlantic climatic episode, c. 1100 B.P. Most Iroquoian farmers benefited from the tempering effects of the lower Great Lakes as well as from the abundant precipitation produced by them.' [513] 'Iroquoians occupied an extension of the level lowlands of the Midwest referred to as the "prairie peninSUla." Most groups lived on an ecotone formed by the boundary of this zone with surrounding uplands or rocky areas-the Canadian shield in Ontario, the Appalachian plateaus in New York and Pennsylvania, and the Laurentian upland in Quebec. Initial settlements were in valleys, but later villages moved into hilly terrain.' [514] 'Iroquoian farmers occupied the limestone regions of the Northeast coincident with the ancient Devonian ocean bottom forming their lowland territory. Limestone bedrocks contained chert outcrops, which provided raw material for chipped-stone tools. The surrounding uplands of volcanic bedrock provided basalt and diabase for ground-stone tools. The main benefit of limestone is that it promotes the growth of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in beans, which were the Iroquoians' major source of fertilizer for maize. The earliest settlements were situated on easily tilled, al- though easily leached, glacial outwash sands. Later, settlements moved onto heavier, loamier, and horticul- turally more durable glacial tills in uplands.' [515] 'Iroquoians lived in the Canadian and Carolinian biotic provinces characterized by mast-producing hardwood forests: oak-maple-beech in the north (Cana- dian) and oak-hickory-chestnut in the south (Carolinian). The mast supported abundant herds of whitetail deer and flocks of turkey and passenger pigeon. Nearby the Iroquoians' villages were large wetlands situated along the flyways of migratory waterfowl. The major rivers and lakes provided schools of anadromous fish, such as salmon, as well as catadromous species-in particular, eel.' [516] 'Iroquoians lived year-round in semi sedentary villages. They moved their villages every 10 to 25 years, for a distance of several kilometers, because of depleted soil fertility and/or firewood. The earliest farming villages were small-roughly 0.5 ha-and were dispersed in valleys across the region. Through time, villages coalesced and grew in size. Tribal clusters consisting of one to four villages formed and were distributed roughly every 50 km across the region, leaving hinterlands between that served as the tribes' hunting grounds. By the end of the period, villages grew by accretion to huge proportions-up to several hectares-and were surrounded by satellite horticultural camps needed to support the village populations of a thousand or more individuals.' [517] 'Villages were placed in de- fensible locations and moved farther from navigable waterways through time. Villages were nearly always fortified with a palisade line supported by an earth embankment with a ditch to the outside and with one or two gates. Longhouses were built inside the palisade and were arranged at random initially. Over time, longhouses became larger, more numerous, and packed tightly in parallel alignment in the direction of the prevailing winds in order to prevent fires from spreading from one house to another. Trash middens were accumulated between longhouses and outside the palisade gates. Cemeteries were generally placed immediately outside the village.' [518] 'Longhouses were occupied by matrilineages and grew through time, presumably as lineages grew in size. Longhouses began as oval wigwams and through time increased in length to upwards of 100-130 m. Longhouses varied in length even within the same village and varied in style in terms of the type of end-square or rounded-and the type of roof-pitched or arced. Longhouses were built of cedar posts covered with slabs of elm bark in the south and cedar bark in the north. Longhouses were uniformally 7 m wide, contained bunk lines along the walls and fire hearths down the center aisle, and were often divided into compart ments 4 m long. Two nuclear families would share a compartment and one fire hearth. The ends of the longhouses were usually reserved for large bark casks holding shelled corn.' [519] 'Typical Iroquoian villages grew in size over time from populations of a couple hundred to a thousand or more. By the time of Contact, each of the Iroquoian tribes had reached population sizes of approximately 4000. Confederacies of tribes that existed at Contact, for example the Huron in Ontario and the Five Nations in New York, numbered approximately 20,000 individuals each. The total population of all tribes in Ontario is estimated to have been 60,000 and that in New York 40,000-50,000. Population growth was largely through adoption of captives. Natural growth was limited by the fact that Iroquoian women could care for only one child at a time while tending the crops, and so practiced birth control through prolonged nursing and use of abortative herbs.' [520] 'Analysis of carbon isotopes in human bones reveals that the Iroquoian diet consisted of at least 50 percent maize. With this starchy diet came a high incidence of dental caries and periodontal diseases. Instances of iron deficiency anemia have been observed in some individuals, indicating a shortage of meat in their diets. The crowded and unsanitary living conditions probably promoted such diseases as tuberculosis, which evidence suggests existed prior to Contact. Following Contact, between 1634-1637, smallpox ravaged many Iroquoian communities and led to severe population loss-up to 60 percent.' [521] 'The primary Iroquoian foods were maize grown by women and fish and game procured by men.' [522] 'Wild Foods. Nuts, acorns, and ground nuts (wild potato or Apios americana) were gathered, particularly during times of crop shortfall. Strawberries were gathered ceremoniously each spring from abandoned agricultural fields. The primary game animal at most villages was deer. At certain times and places, this was surpassed by "garden hunted" species, including racoon and woodchuck, probably as a result of deer herd depletion. Passenger pigeon was a prevalent bird species gathered. Fishing was important throughout the region, particularly of schooling species such as whitefish spawning into tributary streams from the large water bodies. Fishing surpassed hunting as a source of protein in certain areas of high population density such as Huronia.' [523] 'Domestic Foods. The primary staples of Iroquoians were the so-called "Three-Sisters" crops: maize, beans, and squash, which were ceremonially interplanted and ritually harvested. The main maize grown was eight-row northern flint, which was boiled in a lye solution of wood ashes to loosen its flinty hulls and then served as the base for "sagamite," or corn soup, into which any available fish, fowl, or meat was added. Dent corn was ground into flour and used for various breads, to which were added ground beans and dried berries. As stated above, maize was heavily relied on, constituting at least 50 percent of the diet. Exceptions were following years of crop failure caused by drought or insect infestations, at which time wild foods were relied upon.' [524] 'Probably the greatest industry in terms of raw materials was the construction of shelter, including longhouses and palisades, from local forest resources. The ubiquity of ground-stone celts on Iroquoian sites is testimony to the thousands of trees that were felled to build villages. The longhouse frames of white cedar posts lashed together with basswood bark rope were covered with sheets of elm bark stripped from trees in the spring when pliable (in the north, cedar bark was used). Besides use for shelter, elm bark was used to build canoes. In a land too warm to support the paper birch tree, elm bark was used instead. On large rivers, such as the Mohawk, dugout canoes were built from single logs-large enough to hold 150 bushels of corn.' [525] 'Besides woodworking, hide working was the next most important industry, as evidenced from the abundance of hide scrapers and bone awls found on sites. Deer hides were tailored into garments for the cold winters: leggings and shirts for men, dresses for women, and moccasins for all.' [526] 'The greatest industry in terms of energy input and output was maize horticulture, although the technology involved was simple. Aside from digging sticks to sow seeds, hoes were used to cultivate the soil and were fashioned from deer scapulae, or shoulder blades. Deer jaws were used after harvest to strip kernals from the cobs. A significant byproduct of the harvest-corn husk-was used as a raw material for making ceremonial masks, tobacco trays, dolls, slippers, and mats.' [527] 'The greatest quantity of paraphernalia was associated with food preparation, especially of maize. Various baskets, sieves, strainers, mortars, pestles, bowls, and ladles were used to prepare and serve maize. Perhaps the most important was the wooden mortar-a log segment standing upright with the top end hollowed out-and the wooden dumbbell pestle used to pound corn meal inside the mortar. Unfortunately, most of these utensils were fashioned of perishable materials and have not survived the archaeological record.' [528] 'Iroquoian longhouses were generally unornamented, although early Contact houses are said to have been adorned on their gable ends with the clan emblems of their occupants. Iroquois men, who frequently engaged in foreign diplomacy, displayed their clan insignia (as well as various geometric designs) as skin tatoos. They smoked tobacco pipes fashioned in animal effigy forms perhaps also signifying clan affiliation (e.g., owl, wolt). Ornamentation on clothing was in the form of dyed porcupine quills. These were used throughout the Eastern Woodlands and were replaced after Contact with wampum and glass beads.' [529] 'Other ornaments possibly conveying clan affiliation were fashioned from bone and shell. With the leisure time afforded by stored crops, Iroquoians were able to spend many winter hours in the longhouse carving bone and shell, using beaver-incisor cutting tools. Combs and hairpins were carved from deer bone and antler. Beads of a variety of animal effigy forms were fashioned from imported marine shell; the duck form seems to have been most popular. Circular pendants, known as run tees, were carved from marine shell plates. The most common form of decoration on these was the "cross-incircle"-a motif common in the Southeast and probably symbolizing the Iroquois belief in the Four Roots of Peace leading into the Tree or Fire of Peace.' [530] 'Related to ornaments were hollowed deer phalanges, or lower leg bones, many of which are perforated at their closed ends. Their function is unknown, but they may have been used as whistles and/or as rattles, being strung onto bands as leg rattles (see Fenton 1978: 318). After Contact, they would have been replaced by copper bells and cones. Another possible function was in the playing of a ball-in-cup game.' [531] 'From prehistoric times and through the historic period, there was a great demand for marine shell by inland Iroquoian groups. Marine shell beads and ornaments had great social significance and were used to bond alliances, and condole the grieving and were ultimately buried with the dead to accompany their spirits to the afterlife. Raw material for beads was traded in the form of whelk columella-the inner core of the spiral whelk shell-obtained from the Chesapeake bay by way of the Susquehanna river. Plates for pendants were obtained from the latter or from Gulf coast conch shells traded hand to hand up the Mississippi river drainage.' [532] 'What was given in exchange for shell is unknown but was probably some perishable commodity. In historic times, beaver pelts were the chief export. In prehistoric times, surplus maize may have been traded, as was historically documented between the Huron and northern Algonquian hunters. Deer hides may have been traded with the more populous horticultural groups to the south. Tobacco was grown by Iroquoians and was undoubtedly traded to surrounding nonhorticultural groups, as it was used for ritual purposes throughout North America. The Mohawk river valley in New York was the source of "Herkimer Diamonds," or quartz crystals, which had ritual significance and were traded by the Mohawk. Onondaga chert, occurring along the Niagara escarpment of New York and Ontario, was traded as an export commodity, as evidenced by its occurrence in outside areas as a highgrade lithic raw material.' [533] 'Trade was carried out by groups of men from the same clan who embarked on long-distance trading expeditions each summer. Traders were accommodated in other villages by affiliates of their same clan. Trade goods were redistributed in a village according to social requirements, for instance, for bride price, compensating the families of murder victims, or condoling the grievmg.' [534] 'Divisional labor was by gender and age and also by moiety, groups of matrilineal clans (see Social Organization below). The Iroquoian world was divided into two domains on the basis of gender. Everything inside the woods edge surrounding the village, including the maize fields, was the domain of women where they grew crops, prepared food, made clothing, and raised children. Beyond the woods edge was men's domain where they hunted, fished, traded, and conducted warfare. Related women cultivated crops together; men hunted and fished and brought the catch back to the longhouse of their wives. This basic division of labor was symbolized in the marriage ritual, by a gift of cornbread from the woman and of venison from the man. Men of each clan segment or moiety cleared the fields and built the village infrastructure, and women cultivated the crops. Children guarded the maize fields against pests, and the harvest chores were shared ceremoniously by everyone in the village. Old men made fishing nets; old women made mats, baskets, and clothing. Men flaked lithic projectile points; women are believed to have flaked their own scrapers and cutting tools. Women made pottery; men made ceramic tobacco pipes. There were no craft specialists, per se, although some of the lithic points and ceramic pots were very fine and were undoubtedly made by more skilled individuals. Specialized activity areas in longhouses, such as hidescraping and flint-knapping areas, have been identified archaeologically and probably represent communal task groups (as in sewing bees) rather than craft specialists.' [535] 'Resources were controlled by clans according to egalitarean principles. Clan matrons apportioned food resources evenly among all the residents of a longhouse. Chiefs within clans controlled trade routes and access to them; clan matrons controlled horticultural labor.' [536] 'Villages were organized according to matrilineages, clans, and-for the Five Nations-moieties. Each longhouse was occupied by an extended family related along the female line, including the husbands of the related women. Matrilineages belonged to one or more-up to eight--clans that traced their ancestry to a common female. Where ancestry was forgotten, clans served as fictive kin groups and functioned to accommodate visitors of the same clan from outside villages traveling on trading expeditions. Clans maintained various medicine societies and maintained a set of names that were assigned to its members. Clans were organized into one of two moieties. Among the Five-Nations Iroquois, the Father or Older Brother moiety consisted of the Turtle clan and clans of various mammals, while the Female or Younger Brother moiety consisted of the Deer clan and clans of various birds. Moieties functioned primarily in the performance of the Condolence Ceremony, where the "clear-minded" moiety condoled the grieving and mourning moiety of the deceased. Moieties also were the basis of organization of communal work activities such as house building and of games, such as lacrosse.' [537] 'Traditionally, moieties were exogomous-marriages were prohibited within the same moiety. Through the Contact period, this rule became relaxed. Marriage was monogomous, although often easily broken. Nuclear families were small (see Population above) and consisted ideally of three children. Two families would share one fire hearth and longhouse compartment, and each longhouse would contain 5 to 10 hearths and compartments. Children were raised by the maternal extended family (Fenton 1978: 312). Mother's brother served as the father-figure to her children; the biological father maintained familial obligations to his own clan in another longhouse.' [538] 'Iroquoian society was relatively egalitarean and classless. Certain clan lineages that held chief positions (see Political Organization below) were regarded as noble lineages and had higher status than the rest. Iroquoians ranked their members primarily on the basis of age, specifically, in descending order: ancestors, elders, chiefs, adults, children, infants, and the unborn.' [539] 'Chiefs were appointed within certain matrilineal residential units holding chiefly positions. Not all clans had chiefs, and some clans had more than one chief. Chiefs were selected by clan matrons. When they died, their survivors were condoled in a special condolence ceremony combined with a ceremony to "raise" a new chief in the clan to replace the deceased. All the clan chiefs of a village served on a council, and decisions were made by unanimous consensus of all the chiefs. Oratories, debates, and negotiations were held until full agreement could be reached. Specialized positions of leadership were given to individuals who had proved themselves particularly capable. This applied to positions of war chiefs and orators. Such positions, based on an individuals' skill and not clan affiliation (achieved versus ascribed in anthropological terms), lacked decision-making authority and expired with the death of the individual.' [540] 'The conduct of an individual was controlled by censure from members of his or her moiety. Severe crimes, such as murder, were punishable by payment of reparations to the victim's family in the form of wampum, furs, or other gifts. Otherwise, the behavior of individuals was dictated largely by their dreams. Dreams were believed to be the wishes of the soul, and dream fulfillment was thought to promote good health.' [541] 'Social tensions were directed outside the village. Young men released their aggression on war parties into enemy territory. Male warriors from enemy villages were sought, captured, and returned to the village to be tortured to death. Torture ceremonies were carried out by the entire village with all members participating. This apparently served to vent hostilities, which would otherwise erupt inside the village walls.' [542] 'Warfare was endemic to the Iroquoian homeland and in fact to the whole of the Eastern Woodlands. It was of two basic kinds. "General warfare" (Fenton 1978: 315) was between tribes and was sanctioned by the council of the village initiating the war party on behalf of the whole village. Such warfare may have involved conflict over access to trade routes or hunting or trapping territories. It tended to be serious and may have involved the destruction of whole villages.' [543] '"Private warfare" involved blood feuding between lineages in opposing villages, for example, to avenge the murders of kinsmen. It was initiated by individual warriors with or without consent of the village council. Such conflict was less serious and typically involved ambushing the enemy and taking of captives.' [544] 'In most cases, the goal of warfare was to take captives, especially women and children, to adopt into one's own village. Warfare was controlled by specially appointed war chiefs as noted above. Warriors killed in battle were replaced by their biological male offspring, regardless of clan affiliation.' [545] 'Warfare was apparently deeply rooted, as indicated by its highly ritualized nature. War parties prepared by having a feast of the meat of dogs who symbolized the enemy. They ceremoniously departed at woods' edge, being issued their battle gear and provisions by their wives and families. On return, they were greated at woods' edge, again ceremoniously, according to the outcome of the raid. The fate of any male captives taken, such as adoption or death by torture, was decided by the village council, and in either case the captive's treatment was carried out in a highly ritualized ceremony. In the case of torture, this included ritualized cannibalism.' [546] 'Warfare intensified through the Late Woodland period, as evidenced by an increase in cannibalized human bone on sites, more formidable fortifications around villages, more defensible village locations, and the greater distance of villages from navigable waterways.' [547] 'Five tribes in upper New York state-the Seneca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, and Mohawk-formed a mutual nonaggression pact and defensive alliance against surrounding tribes. This famed "League of the Iroquois" is believed to have been formed some time around the middle of the 16th century, predating the arrival of Europeans in the region. This was followed by the disappearance of the S1. Lawrence Iroquois and the displacement of the Susquehannock Iroquoians a substantial distance down the Susquehanna river. Both these events are believed to have been caused by hostilities from the league. Later in the early Contact period, the Erie and Wenro tribes in western New York were defeated by the league as were ultimately the Huron.' [548] 'The creation myth is similar throughout the Iroquoian region and involves Sky Woman falling from the heavens and landing on the back of a great turtle. She gives birth to a daughter, who in turn gives birth to two sons-a good one and an evil one. The dichotomy of good and evil is a common theme throughout Iroquoian ideology. The creation myth also makes reference to the "first times" when the people were divided into two groups living on either bank of a river; these symbolizing the two moieties of Iroquoian society.' [549] 'Iroquoians generally worshipped the creator, a supreme being. At all ceremonies, they gave thanks to him for creating the world, including the earth, waters, plants, animals, and especially the "life supporters"- the maize, beans, and squash. The Iroquoians believed these cultigens had spirits, called "The Three Sisters" and that they had to be planted together in order to grow well.' [550] 'Common among the Five-Nations tribes is the legend of Deganawida and the formation of the league. The legend holds that Deganawida arrived from across lake Ontario as a peacemaker at a time when the Five Nations were all at war with one another. Deganawida pleaded with the tribes to stop fighting among themselves and to form an alliance. One by one, the tribes joined the alliance until the Five-Nations League was formed. Both this legend and the actual League served to keep the tribes from eventually destroying one another.' [551] 'Shamans, or medicine men and women, were organized into medicine societies in clans, but otherwise did not hold specialized positions. The societies' practices were highly ritualized. The False Face Society conducted dances to cure the ill. Members would offer corn mush and tobacco to the false facespirit, then dance in false-face masks shaking turtleshell rattles to ward of the evil spirits causing the illness.' [552] 'The Husk Face Society was made up of medicine women who would cure the sick among themselves. They held dances during the Midwinter Ceremony (see Ceremonies below) to give thanks to the creator for the year's harvest.' [553] 'Ceremonies were conducted by clans and followed an annual cycle based on the lunar calender. Many of the ceremonies were accompanied by group work activities. Beginning in early spring (March) was the Maple Ceremony, marked by the gathering of maple sap; this was followed by group netting of passenger pigeon flocks and group fishing at weir sites. Next came the planting ceremony, which included group preparation of the fields. In June was the Strawberry Festival, when men stripped pliable elm bark for building houses and canoes. During the summer, there were three maizehoeing ceremonies. These were accompanied by the Thunder Rite, where the great spirit was pleaded to provide rain for the crops. In late summer was the Green Corn Ceremony, when the corn reached its milk stage and was available for feasting. The Harvest Ceremony was accompanied by husking bees where maize was strung into long braids and hung from the longhouse rafters to dry. In the fall, families left the village, dispersing into the forest to hunt deer. Finally, at midwinter, the families returned to the village with their cured meat for the most important ceremony of all: the Midwinter Ceremony. There they gave thanks to the creator for providing the food that would enable them to spend the rest of the winter in the longhouses.' [554] 'One of the most prominent and distinctive forms of Iroquoian art are the wooden masks of grotesque forms carved and worn by members of the False Face Society. These are believed to have their roots in the myth of the Stone Face being-stone carvings of which occur archaeologically on early Iroquoian sites. False face masks were carved out of live, standing basswood trees, and undoubtedly their form became more elaborate with the introduction of iron cutting tools during the Contact period. Cornhusk masks were woven out of cornhusks by members of the Husk Face Society and were worn at the Midwinter Ceremonies. Cornhusk dolls were also made as children's play toys.' [555] 'Another prominent and distinctive form of Iroquoian art was their pottery, which was fine, thin-walled, and carefully decorated, by contrast with the crude pottery of the neighboring Algonquians. Much of the pottery in a given village was strikingly similar in style, reflecting the Iroquoian matrilocal residence system. Collars of pots were often decorated with effigy forms, including human faces.
