A common motif in early Contract period pots was a human skeleton, which was often stylized as a simple rib cage and has often been misidentified as a corncob. The motif may relate to the disease epidemics that ravaged the villages around the time of its popularity.' [556] 'Iroquoians believed that following death the soul left the body and began a journey to the "village of souls" in the sky world to the west. Many of the deceased, in Seneca cemeteries, for example, were buried facing west.' [557] 'Among the Five-Nations Iroquois, death of an individual was followed by the Condolence Ceremony and in the case of chiefs was accompanied by another ceremony to raise a new chief. In the Condolence Ceremony, the moiety of the deceased was condoled by the opposite moiety. In accordance with the legend of Deganawida, 15 strings of wampum were offered to relieve the grief of the mourners. Each string had a specific purpose; the first three were to clear the eyes, ears, and throat of the bereaved.' [558] 'Among the Huron, the Feast of the Dead was held every 10 years or so when a village was moved. The bones of all the family members who had died since the previous feast were gathered and wrapped in bundles. These were placed into a heap along with grave goods in a mass burial. These burials form the ossuaries that are known archaeologically in Ontario and along the shores of lakes Erie and Ontario in New York state.' [559]

The Atlas also provides material on the New York Iroquois (950-370 B.P.): 'Lower Great Lakes basin south of lake Erie (the Erie, Neutral, and Wenro subarea; Guthe 1958; Schock 1974; Sullivan 1996; and White 1961) and south of lake Ontario (the Five-Nations subarea; Bradley 1987; Niemczycki 1984; Pratt 1976; Snow 1995; and Tuck 1971). Includes late-period expansions eastward into the St. Lawrence river valley (Pendergast 1975, 1993) and southward into the Susquehanna river valley (Kent 1984).' [560] 'Thin-walled, grittempered globular pots with castellated collars decorated with incised lines, basal notches, and human face and skeleton effigies; clay tobacco pipes of the elbow/barrel form (early), trumpet form (middle), or effigy form (late); chert arrowheads of the Levanna (early) and Madison (late) forms; sinew stones for making bow strings; ground-stone mullers and pestles for grinding corn; polished stone adzes and celts for girdling trees; carved bone and shell beads, ornaments, and hair combs and pins, along with beaver incisor carving tools; bone awls and chert scrapers for working hides; reworked deer phalanges, turtleshell rattles, and bone flutes (Ritchie 1969).' [561] 'lroquoians in New York occupied the rolling hills between the lake plains oflakes Erie and Ontario and the Appalachian highlands farther inland, namely the Allegheny plateau in the south and the Adirondack mountains in the north (Hasen stab 1996). This zone contains limestone bedrock-based glacial tills and moraines, which supported nitrogen fixation by beans for maize. The number of frostfree days ranges from 180 along the great Lakes shores to less than 100 in the upper elevations of the highlands; 120 were required to grow eight-row northern flint maize. The east ends of lakes Erie and Ontario, as well as the east sides of the Finger lakes and Oneida lake, were subjected to lake-effect rains and tempering breezes, which attracted lroquoian horticulturalists. The region falls in the Carolinian biotic province consisting of oak-hickory-chestnut forests, which provided mast for whitetailed deer and turkey. Running east-west through the heart of the region are the Niagara and Onondaga escarpments, which provided chert for lithic tools. Rivers draining from the highlands into the Great lakes supported anadromous fish such as lake salmon, and the lower elevations contained vast wetlands, which hosted flocks of migratory waterfowl.' [562] 'Villages ranged in size from 0.3 ha to 3 ha and generally increased in size over time. Villages shifted over time from lake and riverside locations into the uplands remote from canoe-navigable waterways (Hasenstab 1996; Ritchie 1969; Ritchie and Funk 1973). Some villages, particularly earlier ones, were situated near falls and portages along canoe routes and may have controlled trade (Hasenstab 1987). Villages were fortified with palisades, and later ones were placed in defensible situations. Longhouses inside the villages increased in length through time to reach mammoth proportions of up to 130 m (Snow 1995; Tuck 1971). Villages typically contained large roasting pits probably used for feasting; some of these contained cannibalized human bone (Tuck 1971). Villages were generally moved every 10-25 years for distances of approximately 3 km (Tuck 1971; White 1961; Wray and Shoff 1953), although some, particularly those of the Onondaga, remained occupied for periods of 80-100 years (Bradley 1987: 22; Tuck 1971: 58). Some tribes had villages with associated smaller villages nearby: in the Onondaga area, these are interpreted as waystations for groups being assimilated (Bradley 1987: 27), and in the Seneca area, they are interpreted as military camps occupied by warriors (Charles Wray, personal communication 1982).' [563] 'The staple foods of the New York Iroquois were the so-called Three-Sisters crops: maize, beans, and squash (Parker 1968). The next most important food item was whitetail deer, which was taken chiefly by hunting with bow and arrow. On the plains of lake Ontario, vast grasslands or "oak openings" were maintained by annual burning in order to attract game. In the hardwood forests of the region, migrating flocks of passenger pigeons would come to roost and were captured with nets. Flocks of migratory waterfowl stopping over in the lowland wetlands were hunted, undoubtedly from canoes. Weirs were set up along the Seneca river and tributaries of the Finger lakes to capture migrating fish such as lake salmon. Freshwater mussel shells are ubiquitous on most village sites and were probably gathered by women and children to supplement game brought home by hunters. Trade was conducted to a limited extent during the prehistoric period; exports included the so-called "Herkimer Diamonds," or quartz crystals, from the Mohawk river valley and Onondaga chert from the Niagara and Onondaga escarpments.' [564] 'Villages were organized within according to matrilineages, clans, and moieties (Morgan 1851; Snow 1994). Each longhouse was occupied by an extended family related along the female line, i.e., a matrilineage. These were organized into clans that traced their ancestry to a common female. Clans maintained various medicine societies and maintained a set of names that were assigned to its members. Clans were organized into one of two moieties. Among the Five-Nations Iroquois, the Father or Older Brother moiety consisted of the Turtle clan and clans of various mammals; the Female or Younger Brother moiety consisted of the Deer clan and clans of various birds. Moieties functioned primarily in the performance of the Condolence Ceremony, where the "clear-minded" moiety condoled the grieving and mourning moiety of the deceased. Moieties also were the basis of organization of communal work activities-such as house building-and of games, such as lacrosse. Traditionally, moieties were exogomous, that is, marriages were prohibited within the same moiety. Society was relatively egalitarian, although certain clan lineages held chief positions and were regarded as noble. Chiefs were appointed within these lineages by clan matrons. When they died, their survivors were condoled in a special condolence ceremony combined with a ceremony to "raise" a new chief in the clan to replace the deceased. All the clan chiefs of a village served on a council, and decisions were made by unanimous consensus. Warfare was controlled by specially appointed war chiefs. Warfare was endemic in the New York Iroquois area, and in most cases its goal was to take captives, especially women and children, to adopt into one's own village. Warfare intensified through the Late Woodland period, as evidenced by an increase in cannibalized human bone on sites, more formidable fortifications around villages, more defensible village locations, and the greater distance of villages from navigable waterways. Some time around 400 B.P., the Five Nations tribes (the Seneca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, and Mohawk) formed a mutual nonaggression pact and defensive alliance against surrounding tribes. This was followed by the disappearance of the St. Lawrence Iroquois and the displacement of the Susquehannock Iroquoians a substantial distance down the Susquehanna river. Later in the early Contact period, the Erie and Wenro tribes in Western New York were defeated by the league as were ultimately the Huron.' [565] 'The Iroquois creation myth makes reference to the "first times" when the people were divided into two groups living on either bank of a river; these symbolizing the two moieties of Iroquois society. The Five Nations worshipped the creator and gave thanks to him for the "life supporters"-the maize, beans, and squash, which they called "The Three Sisters," and believed that they had to be planted together for their spirits to be in harmony (Parker 1968). Shamans or medicine men and women were organized into medicine societies within clans. The False Face Society conducted dances to cure the ill, employing wooden masks of grotesque forms carved and worn by members of the society. These are believed to have their roots in the myth of the Stone Face being-stone carvings of which occur archaeologically on early Iroquois sites. The Husk Face Society was made up of medicine women who would cure the sick among themselves. Death of an individual was followed by the Condolence Ceremony in which the moiety of the deceased was condoled by the opposite moiety. The Iroquois believed that following death the soul left the body and began a journey to the "village of souls" in the sky world to the west. Many of the deceased, in Seneca cemeteries, for example, were buried facing west. Unlike the Ontario Iroquois who practiced ossuary burial, the Five Nations interred their dead in individual graves. Grave goods are rare in prehistoric burials but increase in the proto historic period as early European trade goods filter in. Tribes in the western part of New York were influenced by their Ontario neighbors and practiced ossuary burial (see the Ontario Iroquois subtradition).' [566]

eHRAF provides a general summary of Iroquois political and military history: 'The Iroquoian confederacy was organized sometime between 1400 and A.D. 1600 for the purpose of maintaining peaceful relations between the 5 constituent tribes. Subsequent to European contact relations within the confederacy were sometimes strained as each of the 5 tribes sought to expand and maintain its own interests in the developing fur trade. For the most part, however, the fur trade served to strengthen the confederacy because tribal interests often complemented one another and all gained from acting in concert. The League was skillful at playing French and English interests off against one another to its advantage and thereby was able to play a major role in the economic and political events of northeastern North America during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The Iroquois aggressively maintained and expanded their role in the fur trade and as a result periodically found themselves at war with their neighbors, such as the Huron, Petun, and the Neutral to the West and the Susquehannock to the south. Much of the fighting was done by the Seneca, the most powerful of the Iroquoian tribes. From 1667 to the 1680s the Iroquois maintained friendly relations with the French and during this time Jesuit missions were established among each of the 5 tribes.' [567] 'However, Iroquois aggression and expansion eventually brought them into conflict with the French and, at the same time, into closer alliance with the English. In 1687, 1693 and 1696 French military expeditions raided and burned Iroquois villages and fields. During Queen Anne's War (1702-1713) the Iroquois allied with the English and at the War's end were acknowledged to be British subjects, though they continued to aggressively maintain and extend their middleman role between English traders at Fort Orange (Albany) and native groups farther west. The victory of the English over the French in North America in 1763 weakened the power of the confederacy by undermining the strategic economic and political position of the tribes and by promoting the rapid expansion of White settlement. When the American Revolution broke out in 1775 neither the League as a whole nor even the tribes individually were able to agree on a common course of action. Most of the Iroquois allied with the British and as a result during and after the Revolution were forced from their homelands. In the period following the American Revolution the members of the Iroquois tribes settled on reservations in western New York state, southern Quebec and southern Ontario, where many of their descendants remain today.' [568]

Note: The league was organized in multiple 'nations', clans and councils: 'THE POLITICAL ORGANIZATION of the Iroquois--the system by which decisions were made about problems affecting village, tribe, or confederacy --had three levels. The town or village itself decided local issues like the use of nearby hunting lands, the relocation of houses and cornfields, movement to another site, the acceptance or rejection of visitors, and the raising of war parties. There was a village chiefs' council, numbering up to twenty men, formally organized with a chairman and one or more representatives for each clan. These chiefs were influential men and women, who might be League sachems, warcaptains, warriors, or simply old men who were looked up to and consulted. The council generally met in the presence of the warriors and the women, and rarely diverged in its decisions from the popular consensus, or at least the majority view. This council met in the village's ceremonial longhouse, which usually was merely a large dwelling.' [569] Female lineage elders played an important role on the local level: 'The primary local groups of Iroquois society were the extended household and the village. Each extended family lived in a long bark structure, some of which were from fifty to one hundred and fifty feet in length by sixty in breadth, known as longhouses. Throughout its length was a central passageway in which were located hearths at intervals of ten to twelve feet with each hearth being used by two conjugal families. On both sides of this central passageway were apartments each occupied by a simple family. The composition of the group inhabiting the longhouse appears to have been controlled by the matriarch of a lineage. Influential matriarchs who held a chiefly title tended to group their female relatives around them in the same longhouse.' [570] Various political levels were validated by wampum beads: 'The longhouse owns “wampums” which validate its position as a ritual center but which are rarely brought out. Wampum occasionally figures in the ritual, such as the string of wampum used in the rite of confession. But the significance of wampum generally is that because it is a valuable object, it is used to indicate the significance of the event, either by giving it as a commemoration of the event or as being shown in remembrance of the event. Wampum belts, for example, were given at treaties to indicate good faith in the making of the treaty, and might be brought out to remind others of the treaty. In and of itself, wampum is not sacred.' [571] The central League Council dealt with commonn affairs, with tribal chiefs and councils (as well as the female elders of their respective lineages and more recently created non-hereditary positions) occupying an intermediary position: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes. Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare. Iroquois involvement in the fur trade and war with the French increased the importance and solidarity of the League council and thereby strengthened the confederacy. The strength of the confederacy continued to grow until the time of the American Revolution when Iroquois interests divided between alliances to the British and the American colonists.' [572] 'A Chief was appointed by the oldest woman of the maternal family in which the title descended. Her descendants and those who were related clanwise were his constituents. The matron and the chief tended to reside in the same settlement, for when the Chief removed, the clan had no one to regard with confidence unless he returned for village councils. If the matron removed, local succession was in jeopardy. The results of deliberations by the clan were taken from village councils to the council of the tribe. The ranking clan chiefs residing at a place were the cochiefs of that settlement. All eight of the Seneca chiefs are now concentrated at Tonawanda, but formerly the Seneca had at least four villages, and all the rest save the Oneida had each two or three principal towns with satellite settlements. The tribe thus spoke a common language, it comprised two or more settlements, it was governed by a common council of village chiefs who also represented constituent clans, and they governed a common territory adjacent to the towns. In time all clans were present in all villages, probably about in the same proportions as they are now. As any clan predominated in a settlement, members had to seek mates in the next village, or divide their own house in twain, thus distributing the clans again.' [573] Tribes were composed of matrilineages: 'Matrilineages were organized into 15 matrisibs. Among the Cayuga, Onondaga, Seneca and Tuscarora the matrisibs were further organized into moieties. Among the Mohawk and the Oneida no moiety division was recognized. Descent was matrilineal.' [574] The League Council initially met at Onondaga, but the council fire was extinguished and rekindled in various places during the tribulations of the colonial period: 'The council continued to be composed of hereditary chiefs, who together with the “war chiefs” from 1812 andthe Pine Tree chiefs numbered over 50. The Crown madeno attempt to interfere with the appointment or dismissalof chiefs (Weaver 1975). The chiefs met in the Onondagacouncil house, a log structure near Middleport, two orthree times a year to deliberate in traditional fashionmatters of community interest (Weaver 1963-1974). The Onondagas, known collectively as the firekeepers, actedas mediators in the proceedings according to traditionalcustom. However, the tribal seating plan differed fromthe traditional one in that the Mohawks and Senecasoccupied the positions east of the council fire, while theOneidas and Cayugas sat on the west, together with thedependent nations: Tuscaroras, Nanticokes, Delawares,and Tutelos. Although the dependent nations were tospeak through “their voice,” the Cayugas, in fact theyoften directly addressed the assembly of chiefs, andoperated quite independently, though not equaling theoriginal five nations in power or status.' [575] 'Despite the efforts of the Onondagas at Onondaga tohave them returned to Onondaga, the council fire of theConfederacy and its wampum records remained at BuffaloCreek until after that reservation had been sold andCaptain Cold (“The League of the Iroquois: Its History,Politics, and Ritual,” fig. 11, this vol.), keeper of thecouncil fire and the wampum, had died. In 1847 bothwere moved back to Onondaga (Clark 1849, 1:109, 124).However, a number of Onondagas (approximately 150)continued to live on the Seneca and Tuscarora Reservationsin western New York State, the largest number onthe Allegany Reservation (New York (State) Secretary ofState 1857:507; Fletcher 1888:551; New York (State)Legislature. Assembly 1889:59; U.S. Census Office. 11thCensus 1892:6).' [576] There was no state structure. Accordingly, many of the below variables may not be applicable.

Limits on Power of the Chief Executive[edit]

Legal (formal) limits[edit]

♠ Executive power is separate or independent from military ♣ present ♥ The political organization distinguished between villages, tribes, and the common confederate level: 'THE POLITICAL ORGANIZATION of the Iroquois--the system by which decisions were made about problems affecting village, tribe, or confederacy --had three levels. The town or village itself decided local issues like the use of nearby hunting lands, the relocation of houses and cornfields, movement to another site, the acceptance or rejection of visitors, and the raising of war parties. There was a village chiefs' council, numbering up to twenty men, formally organized with a chairman and one or more representatives for each clan. These chiefs were influential men and women, who might be League sachems, warcaptains, warriors, or simply old men who were looked up to and consulted. The council generally met in the presence of the warriors and the women, and rarely diverged in its decisions from the popular consensus, or at least the majority view. This council met in the village's ceremonial longhouse, which usually was merely a large dwelling.' [577] Distinguished war-leaders were eligible for non-hereditary chieftainships: 'The powers and duties of the sachems and chiefs were entirely of a civil character, and confined, by their organic laws, to the affairs of peace. No sachem could go out to war in his official capacity, as a civil ruler. If disposed to take the war-path, he laid aside his civil office, for the time being, and became a common warrior. It becomes an important inquiry, therefore, to ascertain in whom the military power, was vested. The Iroquois had no distinct class of war-chiefs, raised up and set apart to command in time of war; neither do the sachems or chiefs appear to have possessed the power of appointing such persons as they considered suitable to the post of command. All military operations were left entirely to private enterprise, and to the system of voluntary service, the sachems seeking rather to repress and restrain, than to encourage the martial ardor of the people. Their principal war-captains were to be found among he class called chiefs, many of whom were elected to this office in reward for their military achievements. The singular method of warfare among the Iroquois renders it extremely difficult to obtain a complete and satisfactory explanation of the manner in which their varlike operations were conducted. Their whole civil policy was averse to the concentration of power in the hands of any single individual, but inclined to the opposite principle of division among a number of equals; and this policy they carried into their military as well as through their civil organization. Small bands were, in the first instance, organized by individual leaders, each of which, if they were afterwards united upon the same enterprise, continued under its own captain, and the whole force, as well as the conduct of the expedition, was under their joint management. They appointed no one of their number to absolute command, but the general direction was left open to the strongest will, or the most persuasive voice.' [578] 'When the power of the Ho-de[unknown] -no-sau-nee began to develop, under the new system of oligarchies within an oligarchy, there sprang up around the sachems a class of warriors, distinguished for enterprise upon the war-path, and eloquence in council, who demanded some participation in the administration of public affairs. The serious objections to the enlargement of the number of rulers, involving, as it did, changes in the framework of the government, for a long period enabled the sachems to resist the encroachment. In the progress of events, this class became too powerful to be withstood, and the sachems were compelled to raise them up in the subordinate station of chiefs. The title was purely elective, and the reward of merit. Unlike the sachemships, the name was not hereditary in the tribe or family of the individual, but terminated with the chief himself; unless subsequently bestowed by the tribe upon some other person, to preserve it as one of their illustrious names. These chiefs were originally invested with very limited powers, their principal office being that of advisers and counsellors of the sachems. Having thus obtained a foothold in the government, this class, to the number of which there was no limit, gradually enlarged their influence, and from generation to generation drew nearer to an equality with the sachems themselves. By this innovation the government was liberalized, to the sensible diminution of the power of the sachems, which, at the institution of the League, was extremely arbitrary.' [579] Warriors were represented in their own councils: 'Closely allied with the Council of Elders was the women's council who brought the matters up before the council. Lafitau maintained: Separate from both the women's and elder's councils was the warriors' council which sought to influence authority decisions of the council of elders because they were the soldiers or ‘police’ of the village. Their internal affairs idsally were limited to military raids, games, and carrying out the military policy of the council of elders or League Council. In addition to the various councils, asseciations of men and women possibly existed for curing. Lafitau noted “I have been told that they have several sorts of private associations like fraternities” (Ibdd.:476). Fenton speculated that these associations were procursers of the “medicine societies” (Lafitau, 1724, 1:476). However, these associations seem to be the actual medicine societies and as such would have been village groups that criss-cross lineage, clan and moiety statuses.' [580] Accordingly, some separation was present, although the material may more accurately reflect the pre-reservation period.
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from legislative ♣ absent ♥ There was no legislative in the sense of a separate institution. Councils combined legislative, executive and judicial duties: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes.' [581] 'Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare.' [582] 'Iroquois involvement in the fur trade and war with the French increased the importance and solidarity of the League council and thereby strengthened the confederacy. The strength of the confederacy continued to grow until the time of the American Revolution when Iroquois interests divided between alliances to the British and the American colonists.' [583]
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from judiciary ♣ absent ♥ According to L.H. Morgan, there was no formal penal code. Chiefs and councils doubled as judicial authorities: 'Crimes and offences were so unfrequent under their social system, that the Iroquois can scarcely be said to have had a criminal code. Yet there were certain misdemeanors which fell under the judicial cognizance of the sachems, and were punished by them in proportion to their magnitude. Witchcraft was punishable with death. Any person could take the life of a witch when discovered in the act. If this was not done, a council was called, and the witch arraigned before it, in the presence of the accuser. A full confession, with a promise of amendment, secured a discharge. But if the accusation was denied, witnesses were called and examined concerning the circumstances of the case; and if they established the charge to the satisfaction of the council, which they rarely failed to do, condemnation followed, with a sentence of death. The witch was then delivered over to such executioners as volunteered for the purpose, and by them was led away to punishment. After the decision of the council, the relatives of the witch gave him up to his doom without a murmur.' [584] But according to Lyford, there was an orally transmitted constitution validated by wampum beads: 'The League of the Iroquois was governed by a carefully worked out constitution that was transmitted orally from one generation to another by certain leaders (lords or sachems) whose business it was to learn and to recite the laws and regulations. For many generations these laws and regulations were recorded in a collection of wampum belts and strings, twenty-five of which are preserved today in the New York State Museum, whose director has been proclaimed “the keeper of the wampums.”' [585] Council houses combined judicial, executive, and legislative with ceremonial functions, but were also residential: 'In 1818, Timothy Alden (1827:54-55) described a similar council house at Tonawanda. It was fifty feet long and twenty wide. On each side of it, longitudinally is a platform, a little more than one foot high and four feet wide, covered with furs, which furnishes a convenient place for sitting, lounging, and sleeping. A rail across the centre separates the males from the females, who are constant attendants and listen, with silence, diligence, and interest, to whatever is delivered in council. Over the platform is a kind of galley, five or six feet from the floor, which is loaded with peltry, corn, implements of hunting, and a variety of other articles. At each end of the building is a door, and near each door, within, was the council fire. . . . Over each fire several large kettles of soup were hanging and boiling. The smoke was conveyed away through apertures in the roof and did not annoy. The chiefs and others, as many as could be accommodated, in their appropriate grotesque habiliments, were seated on the platform, smoking calumets, of various forms, sizes, and materials, several of which were tendered to me in token of friendship. Profound silence pervaded the crowded assembly.' [586] Accordingly, there were no separate judicial authorities.

Legal (formal) freedoms[edit]

♠ Right to petition executive ♣ present ♥ Women did not usually speak at council meetings, but could influence the decision-making process in other ways: 'The literature stresses the “high position of women” in respect to their participation in dominantly male-oriented cultural activities, especially politics and religion. The political points are familiar and most of them can be traced to the symbolic extension of the Longhouse as the conceptual basis of the League. The extended family structure of the Longhouse, symbolized in the League, accounts for the function of the matrons to hold the chiefs' names in their clans and their consequent right to appoint and depose chiefs. Death feasts and mourning were the responsibility of the women. Women kept the White Wampum belts which signified the chiefly names. The ability of [Page 172] the women to influence decisions of the council both directly through their speaker and indirectly through the weight of public opinion is mentioned in the literature. Since unanimity was necessary for a decision to act, any proposal unpopular with the matrons could be hindered by their disapproval. Indirectly, too, it is stated that the women could hinder or actually prevent a war party which lacked their approval by not giving the supplies of dried corn and the moccasins which the warriors required. Village head-women are mentioned in myth, and though they may not actually have ruled villages, this concept reflects the power that women were thought to possess. The importance of clan matrons in deciding the fate of captives, whether they would be adopted to replace a lost clan member, or tortured as revenge for a death within the clan, is well known.' [587] 'Allusion has been made to the fact that Iroquois women, however influential politically and socially, did not speak in their councils. Early writers take notice of this, and the custom continued. In 1791 Colonel Proctor attended a Seneca feast, where he saw a wooden statue before which they danced. “Under this statue were placed two chiefs, termed the women's speakers. . . . The old and the young women danced around in a circle,” etc. The same gentleman went to a council in Buffalo that year, to “hear what would be said by the women speaker, the young prince of the Turtle tribe (Red Jacket). . . . Being arrived, the first matter unusual that presented itself were the elders of the women seated near the chiefs.” Red Jacket gave their plea for peace.' [588] 'If the women could not or would not always prevent war they often caused it to stop. At a conference at Niagara in 1767, the commissary “was informed that the old women of the Sinecas had stopt their young men from going to war.” They are credited with more power of this kind than they probably had, but they always claimed a share in public affairs. At a council in Albany in 1788, Good Peter, an Oneida chief, after speaking for the men, delivered the women's message. “You have heard our voice; we now entreat [Page 87] you to open your ears and hear a speech from our sisters, the governesses.' [589] Women had their own councils: 'Closely allied with the Council of Elders was the women's council who brought the matters up before the council. Lafitau maintained: The women are always the first who should deliberate according to their principles on private or community matters. They hold their councils apart, and as a result of their decisions advise the chiefs on matters on the mat. (1724, 1:477) Separate from both the women's and elder's councils was the warriors' council which sought to influence authority decisions of the council of elders because they were the soldiers or ‘police’ of the village. Their internal affairs idsally were limited to military raids, games, [Page 25] and carrying out the military policy of the council of elders or League Council. In addition to the various councils, asseciations of men and women possibly existed for curing. Lafitau noted “I have been told that they have several sorts of private associations like fraternities” (Ibdd.:476). Fenton speculated that these associations were procursers of the “medicine societies” (Lafitau, 1724, 1:476). However, these associations seem to be the actual medicine societies and as such would have been village groups that criss-cross lineage, clan and moiety statuses.' [590]
♠ Critique of executive by government ♣ absent ♥
♠ Critique of executive by non-government ♣ present ♥ See above.

Power distributed[edit]

♠ Sanction of executive by government ♣ absent ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by non-government ♣ present ♥ See below.
♠ Constraint on executive by government ♣ absent ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by non-government ♣ present ♥ Matrisibs could nominate and 'dehorn' chiefs: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes.' [591] 'Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare.' [592]
♠ Impeachment ♣ present ♥ See below.

Customary (informal) checks on executive[edit]

♠ Informal critique of executive ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Informal sanction of executive ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Informal constraint on executive ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Informal impeachment ♣ present ♥ Matrisibs could nominate and 'dehorn' chiefs: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes.' [593] 'Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare.' [594]

Limits on executive power imposed by religious agents[edit]

♠ Critique of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious institutions ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Subordination of the chief executive to a religious agent ♣ ♥
♠ Motivation by belief in supernatural agent ♣ ♥

Mechanisms of Power Transfer (from one head of state to the next)[edit]

♠ Customary mechanism ♣ present ♥ Matrisibs nominated hereditary chiefs: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes.' [595] 'Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare.' [596] 'Iroquois involvement in the fur trade and war with the French increased the importance and solidarity of the League council and thereby strengthened the confederacy. The strength of the confederacy continued to grow until the time of the American Revolution when Iroquois interests divided between alliances to the British and the American colonists.' [597]
♠ Legal mechanism ♣ absent ♥
♠ Number of power transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of contested transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of successful overturns ♣ ♥

Central Bureaucracy[edit]

♠ State-level administrators ♣ absent ♥

♠ Prestige of state-level bureaucracy ♣ absent ♥ Note: The political system of the league was not bureaucratic. Wallace provides a general summary: 'THE POLITICAL ORGANIZATION of the Iroquois--the system by which decisions were made about problems affecting village, tribe, or confederacy --had three levels. The town or village itself decided local issues like the use of nearby hunting lands, the relocation of houses and cornfields, movement to another site, the acceptance or rejection of visitors, and the raising of war parties. There was a village chiefs' council, numbering up to twenty men, formally organized with a chairman and one or more representatives for each clan. These chiefs were influential men and women, who might be League sachems, warcaptains, warriors, or simply old men who were looked up to and consulted. The council generally met in the presence of the warriors and the women, and rarely diverged in its decisions from the popular consensus, or at least the majority view. This council met in the village's ceremonial longhouse, which usually was merely a large dwelling.' [598] Female lineage elders played an important role on the local level: 'The primary local groups of Iroquois society were the extended household and the village. Each extended family lived in a long bark structure, some of which were from fifty to one hundred and fifty feet in length by sixty in breadth, known as longhouses. Throughout its length was a central passageway in which were located hearths at intervals of ten to twelve feet with each hearth being used by two conjugal families. On both sides of this central passageway were apartments each occupied by a simple family. The composition of the group inhabiting the longhouse appears to have been controlled by the matriarch of a lineage. Influential matriarchs who held a chiefly title tended to group their female relatives around them in the same longhouse.' [599] Various political levels were validated by wampum beads: 'The longhouse owns “wampums” which validate its position as a ritual center but which are rarely brought out. Wampum occasionally figures in the ritual, such as the string of wampum used in the rite of confession. But the significance of wampum generally is that because it is a valuable object, it is used to indicate the significance of the event, either by giving it as a commemoration of the event or as being shown in remembrance of the event. Wampum belts, for example, were given at treaties to indicate good faith in the making of the treaty, and might be brought out to remind others of the treaty. In and of itself, wampum is not sacred.' [600] The central League Council dealt with commonn affairs, with tribal chiefs and councils (as well as the female elders of their respective lineages and more recently created non-hereditary positions) occupying an intermediary position: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes. Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare. Iroquois involvement in the fur trade and war with the French increased the importance and solidarity of the League council and thereby strengthened the confederacy. The strength of the confederacy continued to grow until the time of the American Revolution when Iroquois interests divided between alliances to the British and the American colonists.' [601] 'A Chief was appointed by the oldest woman of the maternal family in which the title descended. Her descendants and those who were related clanwise were his constituents. The matron and the chief tended to reside in the same settlement, for when the Chief removed, the clan had no one to regard with confidence unless he returned for village councils. If the matron removed, local succession was in jeopardy. The results of deliberations by the clan were taken from village councils to the council of the tribe. The ranking clan chiefs residing at a place were the cochiefs of that settlement. All eight of the Seneca chiefs are now concentrated at Tonawanda, but formerly the Seneca had at least four villages, and all the rest save the Oneida had each two or three principal towns with satellite settlements. The tribe thus spoke a common language, it comprised two or more settlements, it was governed by a common council of village chiefs who also represented constituent clans, and they governed a common territory adjacent to the towns. In time all clans were present in all villages, probably about in the same proportions as they are now. As any clan predominated in a settlement, members had to seek mates in the next village, or divide their own house in twain, thus distributing the clans again.' [602] Tribes were composed of matrilineages: 'Matrilineages were organized into 15 matrisibs. Among the Cayuga, Onondaga, Seneca and Tuscarora the matrisibs were further organized into moieties. Among the Mohawk and the Oneida no moiety division was recognized. Descent was matrilineal.' [603] The League Council initially met at Onondaga, but the council fire was extinguished and rekindled in various places during the tribulations of the colonial period: 'The council continued to be composed of hereditary chiefs, who together with the “war chiefs” from 1812 andthe Pine Tree chiefs numbered over 50. The Crown madeno attempt to interfere with the appointment or dismissalof chiefs (Weaver 1975). The chiefs met in the Onondagacouncil house, a log structure near Middleport, two orthree times a year to deliberate in traditional fashionmatters of community interest (Weaver 1963-1974). The Onondagas, known collectively as the firekeepers, actedas mediators in the proceedings according to traditionalcustom. However, the tribal seating plan differed fromthe traditional one in that the Mohawks and Senecasoccupied the positions east of the council fire, while theOneidas and Cayugas sat on the west, together with thedependent nations: Tuscaroras, Nanticokes, Delawares,and Tutelos. Although the dependent nations were tospeak through “their voice,” the Cayugas, in fact theyoften directly addressed the assembly of chiefs, andoperated quite independently, though not equaling theoriginal five nations in power or status.' [604] 'Despite the efforts of the Onondagas at Onondaga tohave them returned to Onondaga, the council fire of theConfederacy and its wampum records remained at BuffaloCreek until after that reservation had been sold andCaptain Cold (“The League of the Iroquois: Its History,Politics, and Ritual,” fig. 11, this vol.), keeper of thecouncil fire and the wampum, had died. In 1847 bothwere moved back to Onondaga (Clark 1849, 1:109, 124).However, a number of Onondagas (approximately 150)continued to live on the Seneca and Tuscarora Reservationsin western New York State, the largest number onthe Allegany Reservation (New York (State) Secretary ofState 1857:507; Fletcher 1888:551; New York (State)Legislature. Assembly 1889:59; U.S. Census Office. 11thCensus 1892:6).' [605] Accordingly, the below variables are not applicable to the Iroquois.

Authority over state-level administrators

♠ Direct ♣ ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ ♥
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ ♥

Source of Support of state-level officials

♠ State salary ♣ ♥
♠ Governed population ♣ ♥
♠ Land ♣ ♥
♠ None ♣ ♥
♠ Other ♣ ♥

Pathologies

♠ Corruption ♣ ♥
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥

♠ Professionalization of state-level bureaucracy ♣ ♥

♠ modal number of years state-level bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥

♠ Promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ ♥

♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ ♥

♠ Promotion from lower ranks ♣ ♥

♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials from lower ranks ♣ ♥

Local-level officials (provincial, regional, civic administration)[edit]

♠ Number of regional administrative units ♣ ♥

♠ Local-level administrators ♣ absent ♥ Note: The political system of the league was not bureaucratic. Wallace provides a general summary: 'THE POLITICAL ORGANIZATION of the Iroquois--the system by which decisions were made about problems affecting village, tribe, or confederacy --had three levels. The town or village itself decided local issues like the use of nearby hunting lands, the relocation of houses and cornfields, movement to another site, the acceptance or rejection of visitors, and the raising of war parties. There was a village chiefs' council, numbering up to twenty men, formally organized with a chairman and one or more representatives for each clan. These chiefs were influential men and women, who might be League sachems, warcaptains, warriors, or simply old men who were looked up to and consulted. The council generally met in the presence of the warriors and the women, and rarely diverged in its decisions from the popular consensus, or at least the majority view. This council met in the village's ceremonial longhouse, which usually was merely a large dwelling.' [606] Female lineage elders played an important role on the local level: 'The primary local groups of Iroquois society were the extended household and the village. Each extended family lived in a long bark structure, some of which were from fifty to one hundred and fifty feet in length by sixty in breadth, known as longhouses. Throughout its length was a central passageway in which were located hearths at intervals of ten to twelve feet with each hearth being used by two conjugal families. On both sides of this central passageway were apartments each occupied by a simple family. The composition of the group inhabiting the longhouse appears to have been controlled by the matriarch of a lineage. Influential matriarchs who held a chiefly title tended to group their female relatives around them in the same longhouse.' [607] Various political levels were validated by wampum beads: 'The longhouse owns “wampums” which validate its position as a ritual center but which are rarely brought out. Wampum occasionally figures in the ritual, such as the string of wampum used in the rite of confession. But the significance of wampum generally is that because it is a valuable object, it is used to indicate the significance of the event, either by giving it as a commemoration of the event or as being shown in remembrance of the event. Wampum belts, for example, were given at treaties to indicate good faith in the making of the treaty, and might be brought out to remind others of the treaty. In and of itself, wampum is not sacred.' [608] The central League Council dealt with commonn affairs, with tribal chiefs and councils (as well as the female elders of their respective lineages and more recently created non-hereditary positions) occupying an intermediary position: 'The Iroquois confederacy operated under a council of 50 sachems representing the five original tribes. When the Tuscarora joined the League in 1722, no new sachem positions were created for it. The council was a legislative, executive and judicial body that deliberated only on the external affairs of the confederacy, such as peace and war, and on matters common to the five constituent tribes. The council had no voice in the internal affairs of the separate tribes. Tribal representation on the council was unequally distributed among the 5 tribes although abuse of power was limited by the requirement of unanimity in all council decisions. Below the level of the League council were separate tribal councils concerned with the internal affairs of each tribe and each tribe's relations with external groups. The tribal council was composed of the sachems who represented the tribe on the League council. Sachem positions were hereditary within each tribe and belonged to particular matrisibs. The women of the matrisib nominated each new sachem, who was always a male, and had the power to recall or "dehorn" a chief who failed to represent the interests of his people. Theoretically, each sachem was equal to the others in power, but in practice those with better oratorial skills wielded greater influence. After the confederacy had been functioning for a period of time a new, nonhereditary office of Pine Tree Chief was created to provide local leadership and to act as advisors to the council sachems, although later they actually sat on the League council and equaled the sachems in power. Pine Tree Chiefs held their position for life and were chosen by the women of a matrisib on the basis of skill in warfare. Iroquois involvement in the fur trade and war with the French increased the importance and solidarity of the League council and thereby strengthened the confederacy. The strength of the confederacy continued to grow until the time of the American Revolution when Iroquois interests divided between alliances to the British and the American colonists.' [609] 'A Chief was appointed by the oldest woman of the maternal family in which the title descended. Her descendants and those who were related clanwise were his constituents. The matron and the chief tended to reside in the same settlement, for when the Chief removed, the clan had no one to regard with confidence unless he returned for village councils. If the matron removed, local succession was in jeopardy. The results of deliberations by the clan were taken from village councils to the council of the tribe. The ranking clan chiefs residing at a place were the cochiefs of that settlement. All eight of the Seneca chiefs are now concentrated at Tonawanda, but formerly the Seneca had at least four villages, and all the rest save the Oneida had each two or three principal towns with satellite settlements. The tribe thus spoke a common language, it comprised two or more settlements, it was governed by a common council of village chiefs who also represented constituent clans, and they governed a common territory adjacent to the towns. In time all clans were present in all villages, probably about in the same proportions as they are now. As any clan predominated in a settlement, members had to seek mates in the next village, or divide their own house in twain, thus distributing the clans again.' [610] Tribes were composed of matrilineages: 'Matrilineages were organized into 15 matrisibs. Among the Cayuga, Onondaga, Seneca and Tuscarora the matrisibs were further organized into moieties. Among the Mohawk and the Oneida no moiety division was recognized. Descent was matrilineal.' [611] The League Council initially met at Onondaga, but the council fire was extinguished and rekindled in various places during the tribulations of the colonial period: 'The council continued to be composed of hereditary chiefs, who together with the “war chiefs” from 1812 andthe Pine Tree chiefs numbered over 50. The Crown madeno attempt to interfere with the appointment or dismissalof chiefs (Weaver 1975). The chiefs met in the Onondagacouncil house, a log structure near Middleport, two orthree times a year to deliberate in traditional fashionmatters of community interest (Weaver 1963-1974). The Onondagas, known collectively as the firekeepers, actedas mediators in the proceedings according to traditionalcustom. However, the tribal seating plan differed fromthe traditional one in that the Mohawks and Senecasoccupied the positions east of the council fire, while theOneidas and Cayugas sat on the west, together with thedependent nations: Tuscaroras, Nanticokes, Delawares,and Tutelos. Although the dependent nations were tospeak through “their voice,” the Cayugas, in fact theyoften directly addressed the assembly of chiefs, andoperated quite independently, though not equaling theoriginal five nations in power or status.' [612] 'Despite the efforts of the Onondagas at Onondaga tohave them returned to Onondaga, the council fire of theConfederacy and its wampum records remained at BuffaloCreek until after that reservation had been sold andCaptain Cold (“The League of the Iroquois: Its History,Politics, and Ritual,” fig. 11, this vol.), keeper of thecouncil fire and the wampum, had died. In 1847 bothwere moved back to Onondaga (Clark 1849, 1:109, 124).However, a number of Onondagas (approximately 150)continued to live on the Seneca and Tuscarora Reservationsin western New York State, the largest number onthe Allegany Reservation (New York (State) Secretary ofState 1857:507; Fletcher 1888:551; New York (State)Legislature. Assembly 1889:59; U.S. Census Office. 11thCensus 1892:6).' [613] ccordingly, the below variables are not applicable to the Iroquois.

Authority over local-level administrators

♠ Direct ♣ ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ ♥
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ ♥

Source of Support of local-level officials

♠ State salary ♣ ♥
♠ Governed population ♣ ♥
♠ Land ♣ ♥
♠ None ♣ ♥
♠ Other ♣ ♥

Pathologies

♠ Corruption ♣ ♥
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥

♠ Professionalization of local bureaucracy ♣ ♥

♠ modal number of years local bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥

Legal System[edit]

♠ Multiple legal systems ♣ absent ♥ Note: According to L.H. Morgan, there was no formal penal code. Chiefs and councils doubled as judicial authorities: 'Crimes and offences were so unfrequent under their social system, that the Iroquois can scarcely be said to have had a criminal code. Yet there were certain misdemeanors which fell under the judicial cognizance of the sachems, and were punished by them in proportion to their magnitude. Witchcraft was punishable with death. Any person could take the life of a witch when discovered in the act. If this was not done, a council was called, and the witch arraigned before it, in the presence of the accuser. A full confession, with a promise of amendment, secured a discharge. But if the accusation was denied, witnesses were called and examined concerning the circumstances of the case; and if they established the charge to the satisfaction of the council, which they rarely failed to do, condemnation followed, with a sentence of death. The witch was then delivered over to such executioners as volunteered for the purpose, and by them was led away to punishment. After the decision of the council, the relatives of the witch gave him up to his doom without a murmur.' [614] But according to Lyford, there was an orally transmitted constitution validated by wampum beads: 'The League of the Iroquois was governed by a carefully worked out constitution that was transmitted orally from one generation to another by certain leaders (lords or sachems) whose business it was to learn and to recite the laws and regulations. For many generations these laws and regulations were recorded in a collection of wampum belts and strings, twenty-five of which are preserved today in the New York State Museum, whose director has been proclaimed “the keeper of the wampums.”' [615] Council houses combined judicial, executive, and legislative with ceremonial functions, but were also residential: 'In 1818, Timothy Alden (1827:54-55) described a similar council house at Tonawanda. It was fifty feet long and twenty wide. On each side of it, longitudinally is a platform, a little more than one foot high and four feet wide, covered with furs, which furnishes a convenient place for sitting, lounging, and sleeping. A rail across the centre separates the males from the females, who are constant attendants and listen, with silence, diligence, and interest, to whatever is delivered in council. Over the platform is a kind of galley, five or six feet from the floor, which is loaded with peltry, corn, implements of hunting, and a variety of other articles. At each end of the building is a door, and near each door, within, was the council fire. . . . Over each fire several large kettles of soup were hanging and boiling. The smoke was conveyed away through apertures in the roof and did not annoy. The chiefs and others, as many as could be accommodated, in their appropriate grotesque habiliments, were seated on the platform, smoking calumets, of various forms, sizes, and materials, several of which were tendered to me in token of friendship. Profound silence pervaded the crowded assembly.' [616] Accordingly, some of the below variables may not be applicable to the Iroquois. We have coded for 'informal justice' instead.

♠ Courts are supported by the state ♣ absent ♥

♠ Criminal Prosecution ♣ absent ♥

Accessibility of the Legal System

♠ ruling elite ♣ ♥
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ ♥
♠ general population ♣ ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ ♥

Accessibility of Trials

♠ ruling elite ♣ ♥
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ ♥
♠ general population ♣ ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ ♥

Accessibility of Courts

♠ Courts in polity capital ♣ absent ♥ Councils doubled as courts.
♠ Courts in regional capitals ♣ absent ♥ Councils doubled as courts.
♠ Courts in provincial towns ♣ absent ♥ Councils doubled as courts.

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in criminal cases ♣ ♥

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in civil cases ♣ ♥

Informal Justice[edit]

♠ Non-state judiciary ♣ present ♥ According to L.H. Morgan, there was no formal penal code. Chiefs and councils doubled as judicial authorities: 'Crimes and offences were so unfrequent under their social system, that the Iroquois can scarcely be said to have had a criminal code. Yet there were certain misdemeanors which fell under the judicial cognizance of the sachems, and were punished by them in proportion to their magnitude. Witchcraft was punishable with death. Any person could take the life of a witch when discovered in the act. If this was not done, a council was called, and the witch arraigned before it, in the presence of the accuser. A full confession, with a promise of amendment, secured a discharge. But if the accusation was denied, witnesses were called and examined concerning the circumstances of the case; and if they established the charge to the satisfaction of the council, which they rarely failed to do, condemnation followed, with a sentence of death. The witch was then delivered over to such executioners as volunteered for the purpose, and by them was led away to punishment. After the decision of the council, the relatives of the witch gave him up to his doom without a murmur.' [617] But according to Lyford, there was an orally transmitted constitution validated by wampum beads: 'The League of the Iroquois was governed by a carefully worked out constitution that was transmitted orally from one generation to another by certain leaders (lords or sachems) whose business it was to learn and to recite the laws and regulations. For many generations these laws and regulations were recorded in a collection of wampum belts and strings, twenty-five of which are preserved today in the New York State Museum, whose director has been proclaimed “the keeper of the wampums.”' [618] Council houses combined judicial, executive, and legislative with ceremonial functions, but were also residential: 'In 1818, Timothy Alden (1827:54-55) described a similar council house at Tonawanda. It was fifty feet long and twenty wide. On each side of it, longitudinally is a platform, a little more than one foot high and four feet wide, covered with furs, which furnishes a convenient place for sitting, lounging, and sleeping. A rail across the centre separates the males from the females, who are constant attendants and listen, with silence, diligence, and interest, to whatever is delivered in council. Over the platform is a kind of galley, five or six feet from the floor, which is loaded with peltry, corn, implements of hunting, and a variety of other articles. At each end of the building is a door, and near each door, within, was the council fire. . . . Over each fire several large kettles of soup were hanging and boiling. The smoke was conveyed away through apertures in the roof and did not annoy. The chiefs and others, as many as could be accommodated, in their appropriate grotesque habiliments, were seated on the platform, smoking calumets, of various forms, sizes, and materials, several of which were tendered to me in token of friendship. Profound silence pervaded the crowded assembly.' [619]

♠ Religious judiciary ♣ present ♥ It appears that Keepers of the Faith played a role in detecting and punishing witches: 'Part time religious specialists known as Keepers of the Faith served in part to censure anti-social behavior. Unconfessed witches detected through council proceedings were punished with death, while those who confessed might be allowed to reform.' [620] More material is needed to confirm this.

Property Rights[edit]

♠ Private property (land) ♣ absent ♥ Iroquois society was organized in matrilineages: 'Matrilineages were organized into 15 matrisibs. Among the Cayuga, Onondaga, Seneca and Tuscarora the matrisibs were further organized into moieties. Among the Mohawk and the Oneida no moiety division was recognized. Descent was matrilineal. In modern times, the stress placed on patrilineal inheritance by Canadian authorities has undermined the traditional matrilineal system.' [621] 'Traditional kinship terminology followed the Iroquoian pattern. In one's own and the first ascending and descending generations parallel relatives were classed with one's lineal relatives and cross relatives were referred to separately.' [622] Property was held and transmitted by the matrilineage: 'Matrilineages were the property holding unit in traditional Iroquoian society.' [623] 'In modern society every foot of ground and every chattel belongs to a person, natural or corporate, or to the state. In an Iroquois tribe there were owners of third class, the houses and clans.' [624] 'Traditionally, property was inherited matrilineally. In the 1980s matrilineal inheritance continued to be practiced among Iroquois on reservations in the United States, but not so for those in Canada, where the government has enforced a patrilineal system of inheritance.' [625] The same was true of titles: 'As the whole Iroquois system rested upon the tribes as an organic division of the people, it was very natural that the separate rights of each should be jealously guarded. Not the least remarkable among their institutions, was that which confined the transmission of all titles, rights and property in the [Page [facing p. 79]] [Page 80] female line to the exclusion of the male. It is strangely unlike the canons of descent adopted by civilized nations, but it secured several important objects. If the Deer tribe of the Cayugas, for example, received a sachemship at the original distribution of these offices, the descent of such title being limited to the female line, it could never pass out of the tribe. It thus became instrumental in giving to the tribe individuality. A still more marked result, and perhaps a leading object of this enactment was the perpetual disinheritance of the son. (57) Being of the tribe of his mother formed an impassable barrier against him; and he could neither succeed his father as a sachem, nor inherit from him even his medal, or his tomahawk. (103) The inheritance, for the protection of tribal rights, was thus directed from the lineal descendants of the sachem, to his brothers, or his sisters' children, or, under certain circumstances, to some individual of the tribe at large; each and all of whom were in his tribe, while his children, being in another tribe, as before remarked, were placed out of the line of succession.' [626] 'Nations' owned priviledged access to natural resources in their territory: 'Seasonal return to hunting and fishing economy meant that Iroquois villages were abandoned periodically. From the harvest to midwinter, families went to the woods to hunt for meat, seeking hunting partners in settlements adjacent to hunting grounds. Villages were again evacuated in early spring: (1) a short removal to the nearby sugar bush for several weeks, (2) for a longer period in March and April to attend pigeon nestings, and (3) to nearby fishing sites. In all these activities a semblance of local organization was maintained. Village and tribal holdings in sugar bush, pigeon nesting sites, and fishing places formed a continuous territory with the farm and ordinary hunting lands of the village. Major pigeon nestings and longterm fall hunts were carried on at some remove from the village settlements and required the movement of persons from say Buffalo some 70 or 80 miles to south of Warren, Pa. (Fenton and Deardorff, 1943, p. 296 and map). Villages tended to move within rather narrow orbits, quite definitely within the above territory, moving to perhaps a day's walk from the old settlement, frequently the “old town” giving way to the “new town” as a gradual development of one out of the other. At earlier times the movements were more abrupt (Fenton, 1940). Use of hunting territory, fishing sites, berrying grounds, and medicinal plant stations were deemed local privileges belonging to the inhabitants of that place. Ultimately, such ownership rested in the tribe or “nation.” To this day the title of lands rests in the nation; nothing like the Algonquian type of individual hunting territories was known. A Cayuga hunter, however, was careful to leave the pelt in the Seneca nation's territory, vouchsafing a privilege which was not extended to alien tribes outside the League. Similarly the use of fields and cemeteries will redound to local inhabitants. To the extent that coresidents are related unilaterally, [Page 43] clan fields will adjoin; cemeteries will contain the bones of predominately one clan.' [627] Land was thus generally held in common, but individuals retained usufruct rights in lands which they themselves had opened for cultivation: 'Property, both in amount and variety, was exceedingly limited; as would naturally be expected among a people living a hunter and semi-agricultural life, and making a mere subsistence the limit of their wants and of their ambition. But inconsiderable as it was in the aggregate, it was held, and subject to distribution, under fixed laws. Having neither currency nor trade, nor the love of gain, their property consisted merely of planting lots, orchards, houses, implements of the chase, weapons, articles of apparel, domestic utensils, personal ornaments, stores of grain, skins of animals, and those miscellaneous fabrics which the necessities of life led them to invent. The rights of property, of both husband and wife, were continued distinct during the existence of the marriage relation; the wife holding, and controlling her own, the same as her husband, and in case of separation, taking it with her. No individual could obtain the absolute title to land, as that was vested by the laws of the Iroquois in all the people; but he could reduce unoccupied lands to cultivation, to any extent he pleased; and so long as he continued to use them, his right to their enjoyment was protected and secured. He could also sell his improvements, or bequeath them to his wife or children. If the wife, either before or after marriage, inherited orchards, or planting lots, or reduced land to cultivation, she could dispose of them at her pleasure, and in case of her death they were inherited, together with her other effects, by her children. The rule of descent, on the death of the father, was different. His children, not being [Page 318] of his tribe, were out of the line of inheritance; for by their laws, property could not, by descent, pass out of the tribe. If he gave his planting lots, or any articles of property to his wife or children, in the presence of a witness, they were allowed to hold them. But if he made no disposition of his effects, they were handed over upon his decease, to the near relatives in his own tribe, who usually assigned to the family the house, and such other articles as they deemed advisable, and distributed the residue among themselves, as personal mementos of the deceased.' [628] Individually held private property was limited to movables: 'The individual owned, to use a convenient measure, only that he could carry with him; his clothing and ornaments, the mat on which he slept, his weapons, his pipe, and his kettle. These and no more he could take with him when he emigrated, and they were buried with him when he died. As a member of the house, clan, or tribe, he had a special property in other chattels and in land so long as he was in possession and use thereof as a member of the community. But when his relation ended his rights ended also.' [629] However, some differentiation of wealth was present: 'The distinction of rich and poor was known among the Iroquois, as applying both to the individual and to the house. [Page 274] Even in the same clan one house might be wealthy and the other poor. Property rnight be transferred by gift or purchase, by gambling, as a hire of labor, but rather as a fee than a wage, or in payment of damages for a tort.' [630] Morgan speaks of cycles of wealth and poverty: 'The common right in food and other chattels tended naturally to waste and poverty, for no one had the right to reserve that which another might wish to use. This, rather than improvidence properly so called, was the reason why in the Indian household it was commonly either a feast or a famine.' [631] Morgan provides a general summary of the property system: 'The tribe had its property also, -- its lands, tenements, and hereditaments.
