The Longhouse is furnished with two rows of benches along both long walls with additional benches along the short walls (fig. 10). This arrangement provides seating while leaving most of the floor space available for the dancing that is such an important part of the ritual. Most commonly, seating is by age and sex, the women and young children sitting on the benches on both sides at one end of the Longhouse and the men on those at the other end (fig. 11). If the musicians for a dance are to be seated, benches are placed in the middle of the Longhouse for them. The dances are for all, and all who wish to dance (including old people and young ones) do so.' [1,268] Christian communities built churches, but the process of Christianization was slow and did not accelerate significantly until the middle of the 19th century: 'In the early decades of the nineteenth century, variousministers visited the Onondaga and other efforts weremade to convert them, with only limited success. In 1816 Eleazar Williams, an adopted Mohawk catechist and layreader (see “Oneida,” this vol.), visited the Onondagas. Inthat and the following year, a few Onondagas were [Page 497] baptized by Episcopalian clergymen, and subsequentlysome attended the church at Onondaga Hill (Clark 1849,1:238-240). About the same time, a local Presbyterian minister also proselytized among the Onondagas, and in1821 there were said to be 34 who professed Christianityin the Presbyterian form of worship. In 1820 a schooltaught by a Stockbridge woman opened, but the teacherdied a few years later (J. Morse 1822:323-324, 394; Clark1849, 1:240-241). About 1828 a Quaker opened anindustrial school and stayed for six or seven years(Fletcher 1888:551). Nevertheless, there remained considerableopposition to Christian missionaries, and aftera Methodist church was established at Oneida in 1829, Indian exhorters rather than ministers were appointed tovisit Onondaga as the Onondagas remained hostile toChristianity (Clark 1849, 1:241).' [1,269] 'What them was the impotus for change? Most Iroqueis were non-Christian in 1820; however, by 1860 most had become Christian.' [1,270] We have assumed that no separate ritual buildings were present until Christianization in the 19th century.
♠ Other ♣ absent ♥
♠ accessibility of entertainment buildings ♣ ♥

♠ Full-time entertainment specialists ♣ absent ♥ 'One of the most interesting Iroquoian art forms is the False Face Mask. Used in the curing ceremonies of the False Face Societies, the masks are made of maple, white pine, basswood and poplar. False Face Masks are first carved in a living tree, then cut free and painted and decorated. The masks represent spirits who reveal themselves to the mask maker in a prayer and tobacco burning ritual performed before the mask is carved.' [1,271] It appears that art was created by community members, not full-time specialists. Dances and music were also performed by community members, not entertainment specialists. Fenton describes the proceedings at some festivals: 'The ceremony, Thanks-to-the-Maple, which is now obsolete on Allegheny Reservation,used to be celebrated when the sap rose in the spring. Related families gathered inthe morning at Quaker Bridge and Coldspring and separately returned thanks to the mapletrees. Sometimes they danced social dances. At dusk, they sang the songs of Chanters forthe Dead (óhi[unknown] we[unknown] ). The association of this song with the maple is peculiar to QuakerBridge.' [1,272] 'They in time of drought the Thunder Rite is held. The priest burns tobacco and begs thesun not to burn the crops. One moiety represents the sun and the other a shaman. They [Page 9] play at the game of hoop and javelin, which is an appeal to the sun and moon, who derivepleasure from watching it. The side of the sun has the first roll to the westward. Itdoes not matter which side wins. Later the priest makes a second tobacco invocation to theThunderers and they dance the “Sioux” war dance in their honor. “Striking-a-stick”dance follows. Individuals strike the floor, or a signal pole, and implore the Thunderers,their grandfathers, to bring rain to the crops. Some men address themselves to the sun.' [1,273] 'The Green Corn Festival marks the middle of the year. When the corn is ready to eat,late in August or early September, the Faith-keepers gather the community to the longhouseto name children born since the Seneca New Year. The festival lasts four morningsuntil noon, including the preliminary day to name the children. The women's song,(t[unknown] wi[unknown][unknown] sas) occurs on the fourth afternoon after the Bowl Game. Identical in form with thelater three days of the midwinter ritual, which are devoted to the Four Sacred Ceremonies,the Green Corn Festival may extend beyond the minimal number of days, before one moietydefeats the other in the Bowl Game. Then a social dance must be held every evening beforethe game until it is finished. The Green Corn Festival returns thanks to all the spiritforces.It is especially for the vegetables and fruits which have ripened during the season.The Creator and his Appointed-ones are thanked that the crops planted in spring havereached fruition, and he is remembered for life, health and sustenance during the past sixmonths. It is hoped that the winter will not be too severe, and will not approach untilthey have gathered in their crops and gone hunting.' [1,274] 'Every spring and fall two great companies of False Faces go from house to house (hadin[unknown] hd[unknown][unknown] ta[unknown] ). They start at each end of the settlement and approach the longhouse.Carrying pine boughs, they enter every house and drive away all illness, rubbing their turtle shell or bark rattles over the building and whisking the disease spirits from underthe beds. They rout out anyone they find in bed. Their unmasked headman collects tobaccowhich is later used in an invocation. Everyone then repairs to the longhouse where thetwo female officers of the company have prepared a decoction of sunflower seeds and manroot( Ipomoea pandurata ). The whole company is preceded into the building by an unmaskedheadman. He sings the False Faces' song to the winds and Thunderers (ganóiowi[unknown][unknown] ). [Page 10] A similar functionary in the other moiety should burn tobacco. He implores the FalseFaces to keep whirlwinds and pestilences from the village. Before their dance, two maskedmen of opposite moieties pass the medicine to the assembly. Husk Faces watch the doorsand police the longhouse.' [1,275] 'On the third day parties representing each moiety carry paddles bearing their ownclan totems and make the circuit of houses, stirring ashes and singing songs addressed tothe middle pantheon. The rite terminates with the singing of Handsome Lake's own songto the Sun, the Moon and the Thunder. Following the Ashes Stirring Rite, privateparties may make the circuit in response to dreams.' [1,276] 'On the fourth morning a party of dancers, preceded by a leader who announces thatthe time has come to sponsor societies revealed through dreams, and a singer, make thesame circuit of houses, dancing the Great Feather Dance. They receive two ears of cornfor each family in a house. They are followed by a party of women who dance the TraditionalWomen's Dance, carrying ears of corn symbolic of their sisterhood with the foodproducts, Our-life-supporters. These counterclockwise circuits are all marked by gunshotsto announce their departure and return to the longhouse; whereupon Medicine Societyrituals, as requested through dreams, on behalf of those who are ill, or anniversaries ofthose who have been cured, are performed. Anciently this was the first day of dream guessing, after which the guesser, usually one's father's clansman, presented the dreamerwith a miniature guardian representative of the tutelary revealed in the dream and symbolicof the association between him and his clansman's son, which must be renewed annually.' [1,277] 'Commencing this night, parties of youths dressed as False Face beggars go about thehouses begging for tobacco; they steal food for a feast when not rewarded.' [1,278] 'Toward dusk the dances commence again with renewed vigor at the longhouse. Men are appointed to start social dances, which go on simultaneously with medicine rites and theantics of False Face beggars, until the night is capped with the appearance of Those-who-wear-husk-faces.The Husk Faces have previously been heralded by two sets of maskedrunners who signify that their company is approaching the village by racing through thelonghouse from opposite ends. Unlike the False Faces, who wear wooden masks, the HuskFaces have no language. They finally announce their arrival with a great din of beating andrubbing the exterior of the building with staves and wooden shovels. The two heraldsburst into the longhouse, break up the dances, and arrest some elderly man, usually someonewith a sense of humor. They conduct him outside supposedly to interview their leaderwhom he says is a woman. He returns in their custody and delivers her supposed message,but in the middle of it simulates a mock forgetfulness and makes some absurd excuse forgoing outside again to see the Great-wet-woman, whom he says he has not seen for a year.He returns and conducts both sides of a conversation with the masked company. Throughhim, they reveal that they are a race of agriculturists who dwell on the other side of theearth, where they are now hurrying westward to till their crops which grow in fields amidhigh stumps. They describe ears of corn growing to prodigious lengths. They sometimessay they can linger to dance but a few songs with the people of the longhouse, since theirwomen must hasten home to tend to crying babies. Such statements are interpreted asprophecies of good crops and many births. The masked company are dressed to representboth men and women of whom a few carry corn husk dolls wearing miniature husk masks.However, besides being a fertility rite, the ritual presents a humorous situation, since allof the masked actors are men. Their “women” request the privilege of dancing the Traditional Women's Dance to the corn, the beans and the squash, which is the only opportunity [Page 13] for the Seneca men to imitate their wives. Then the male Husk Faces dance the Fish Dancewith the Seneca men; and their wives, who are also men, join in couples like Seneca womenand employ women's dance steps. Mean while the Seneca women also enter in couples anddance opposite the Seneca men, or the male Husk Faces.' [1,279] 'The seventh day marks the celebration of the Great Feather Dance, which is the firstof four ceremonies left by the Creator for the people to enjoy, and later confirmed byHandsome Lake. Since the ceremonies performed on this day comprise the external form ofthe Planting, Strawberry, second day of the Green Corn, and the Harvest Festivals, I willdescribe them below in some detail. In brief, they consist of a first Feather Dance for theFaith-keepers, the Women's Dance, an intermission for changing adult names, installingnew Faith-keepers, or appointing their moiety reciprocates, which occurs only at the NewYear and Green Corn, and the final Great Feather Dance.' [1,280] 'Following this the speaker addresses the assembly, instructing them in the purpose ofthe day's meeting. At the Strawberry Festival he tells them to return thanks for the firstfruits of the earth when they drink the berry juice passed by the Faith-keepers.' [1,281] 'Then he announces the names of the two singers who have been selected from each moiety to sing the Feather Dance, and the two boys, likewise, who will lead it. This firstdance is for the Faith-keepers. They wear no costumes.' [1,282] 'The names of the singers and dancers of the Traditional Women's Dance for the Life-supportersare next announced. The singers are chosen by the women, and a womanleader is appointed for life from each moiety to lead the dance. The women dance carryingears of corn, symbolic of their sister-hood with the Life-supporters, who enter the danceinvisibly. The songs describe the planting, germination, and successive growth of the cornto the time it ripens, is harvested, and put away in the fall. Performance of the rite is athanksgiving for good crops in the past and a hope for better harvests in the future. It epitomizes the association of women with agriculture.' [1,283] 'Then he re-announces the names of the Feather Dance singers and leaders. This is theGreat Feather Dance and all those who would pledge their faith to the ways of their fathersshould go around three times in the dance, or should stand near the singers' bench.' [1,284] 'The Four Sacred Ceremonies are addressed to the Creator. They were given in the creation and confirmed by Handsome Lake. They now form an integral part of the longhousefestivals, and the Seneca look forward to performing them in the hereafter. When aspeaker returns thanks for them, he places them in the sky world. They are the GreatFeather Dance, Personal Chant, Thanksgiving Dance, and the Bowl Game or wager. TheGreat Feather Dance is a costumed dance for men and secondarily women, and the music isprovided by two singers, representing each moiety, who sit facing each other astride abench and pound out an accompaniment with turtle shell rattles which they hold in bothhands. The songs are symbolic of stations in the pantheon. A youth is selected from eachmoiety to lead the dance. He and his partner may receive new names and stand in a reciprocal relationship to each other afterward.' [1,285] 'The Personal Chant is composed of individual thanksgivings for one's wife, one's family,or the life of a “friend,” and the singing of one of many songs which are to some extent theproperty of one's family and possibly of the clan. It is the last song sung by a warrior beforedeath.' [1,286] 'The Thanksgiving or Harvest Dance is a costumed dance for men and women, which isinterspersed by fourteen thanksgiving chants by a priest, who addresses the several groupsof spirit-forces.' [1,287] 'Social dances are numetous. They embrace many dances shared with distant tribes. Quiver or Trotting. Shaking-a-jug. Garter, ‘oshéw[unknown] , Corn, Pigeon, and Duck dances haveforward shuffling steps, in single file, like those of the Bear Society. The Delaware SkinbeatingDance resembles one of the False Face dances. Fish, Coon, Chicken, Choose-a-partnerand Sharperning-a-stick use the dance steps of the Fish Dance. Robin and Shaking-a-bushor Naked dancers maneuver in double columns. The Buffalo Society dancers whirland butt each other. The “Sioux” war dance steps are isolated.' [1,288] 'The Staggering, Chipmunk and Drunken dances are absent, although the last was [Page 18] known anciently at Complanter, and is still performed in Canada. The Knee Rattle Danceis obsolete. Grinding-dishes, Fishing and Alligator dances have been witnessed by myinformants at the Canadian longhouses.' [1,289] 'The Creator's evil brother is credited with social dances, which he intended as hisSacred Ceremonies. Devil Dance (his Feather Dance), Grinding-an-arrow (Harvest Dance),and the Linking-arms Dance, sometimes called Bean (Traditional Women's Dance), werefrowned upon by Handsome Lake. The latter was the only dance permitting physical contactbetween sexes. It is now frequently performed in single file, sometimes using the ancientsongs which ridicule a youth's devotion to an older woman with bumps on her forehead.Carry-out-the-kettle in Chanters for the Dead is the only clockwise dance in Senecaceremonies. The Seneca believe that the ghosts in the other world dance with them.' [1,290] 'Men and women have dancing partners of the same sex in the other moiety. However,in social dances, moiety patterns do not prevail. When women dance behind men, as inmany of the social dances, they must be careful not to dance behind a man to whom theyare not related lest his wife become jealous.' [1,291]

♠ status of full-time entertainment specialists ♣ ♥

♠ Access to education ♣ absent ♥

♠ Publicly funded or subsidized education ♣ absent ♥
♠ Schools for children? ♣ absent ♥ Iroquois children were socialized by elders, parents, and other community members rather than at schools: 'The life cycle pattern of the Iroquois is not well understood. There was a clear dividing line between the activities of men and women and the ideals of male and female behavior and roles were communicated to children by elders through oral traditions. Except for those who achieved political office, no formalized rites of passage marked the transition to adulthood for boys or girls.' [1,292] 'At the age at which sex differentiation entered the socializing process, boys formed age-grade groups which mimicked the hunting and warlike occupations of the men. These groups initiated the process of weaning the males away from the control of the family of orientation. Whereas the training of girls bound them more closely to the family group, the association of the boys with their age mates in the village freed them from kin associations and laid the foundation for future hunting and war parties. When a boy was about fourteen and able to accompany the men on hunting trips, his father and other men of the hunting party took an interest in training him in the use of bow and arrow and other manly weapons. The men of the tribe recounted, for the benefit of the growing generation, their exploits on the warpath in order to instill in the youth ideals of courage and patriotism. The game of la crosse also provided valuable training for the warpath Like his sister, the boy was also influenced by attendance at religious ceremonies where the faithkeepers delivered addresses explaining the system of Iroquois supernaturals and admonishing the people to be thankful and obedient to the Great Spirit and to the moral codes of the nation.' [1,293] Christian missionaries installed schools at reservations, but Christianization did not speed up significantly until the middle of the 19th century (see next data sheet).
♠ Universities, “proto-universities”, or other higher education ♣ absent ♥
♠ Libraries ♣ absent ♥
♠ Museums ♣ absent ♥
♠ Literacy rate ♣ absent ♥ The Iroquois initially relied on wampum records rather than written records: 'The laws explained at different stages of the ceremonial, were repeated from strings of wampum, into which they “had been talked” at the time of their enactment. In the Indian method of expressing the idea, the string, or the belt can tell, by means of an interpreter, the exact law or transaction of which it was made, at the time, the sole evidence. It operates upon the principle of association, and thus seeks to give fidelity to the memory. These strings and belts were the only visible records of the Iroquois; and were of no use except by the aid of those special personages who could draw forth the secret records locked up in their remembrance.' [1,294] Information on Jesuit activities is still needed.

Biological Well-Being[edit]

Mortality

♠ Life expectancy ♣ ♥ Census data are available for the late 19th century: 'During the rural period the population of the reservation increased steadily. An 1855 census gave the population at 2,330. By 1874 the reserve population had increased to 2,992, an increase of over 600 in twenty years (Illustrated Historical Atlas of Brant County, 1875:7). An 1891 census estimated that the reserve population was 3,228 (Canada, 1892, 1:146). By 1911 Knowles (1937) estimated the population at 4,446. The population increase was due to a higher birth rate. Yet the death rate was also high - over thirty per one thousand individuals annually compared with a rate of about ten per thousand for the Province of Ontari. [Page 53] (Boyle, 1898:191; Canada 1900:613). The highest mortality rate occure among infants. A medical officer of the Six Nations reported: The number of deaths of children under one year of age is appalling, especially when it is taken into consideration that a very large percentage of them is due to preventable causes, fully thirty percent of them due to congenital syphilis. (Boyle, 1898:196). The reserve suffered from at least two epidemics of smallpox; however, deaths were minimal due to vaccination. Tuberculesis was a major cause of death in adults, along with pneumonia, malaria and typhoid fever In combating disease the Six Nation Iroquois utilized native and white medical techniques.' [1,295] However, we have found no reliable data on earlier time periods.
♠ Infant mortality ♣ ♥ Census data are available for the late 19th century: 'During the rural period the population of the reservation increased steadily. An 1855 census gave the population at 2,330. By 1874 the reserve population had increased to 2,992, an increase of over 600 in twenty years (Illustrated Historical Atlas of Brant County, 1875:7). An 1891 census estimated that the reserve population was 3,228 (Canada, 1892, 1:146). By 1911 Knowles (1937) estimated the population at 4,446. The population increase was due to a higher birth rate. Yet the death rate was also high - over thirty per one thousand individuals annually compared with a rate of about ten per thousand for the Province of Ontari. [Page 53] (Boyle, 1898:191; Canada 1900:613). The highest mortality rate occure among infants. A medical officer of the Six Nations reported: The number of deaths of children under one year of age is appalling, especially when it is taken into consideration that a very large percentage of them is due to preventable causes, fully thirty percent of them due to congenital syphilis. (Boyle, 1898:196). The reserve suffered from at least two epidemics of smallpox; however, deaths were minimal due to vaccination. Tuberculesis was a major cause of death in adults, along with pneumonia, malaria and typhoid fever In combating disease the Six Nation Iroquois utilized native and white medical techniques.' [1,296] However, we have found no reliable data on earlier time periods.

Disease

♠ Endemic disease ♣ present ♥ Fenton describes 'native' endemic diseases: 'The picture that we have developed of Indian medicines during the period of its failure to cope with introduced European diseases leads us to inquire how successfully native herbalists treated indigenous ailments. Early travelers remark that certain diseases then common among Europeans were unobserved among the northeastern American tribes. Among these, gout, gravel, and dropsy were mentioned by Lahontan. On the other hand, ailments growing out of their way of life were more frequent: prolonged fasts followed by feasts and periods of famine induced digestive disturbances; rheumatism, neuralgia, pleurisy, and pneumonia were not uncommon among the Iroquois; and long years of group living in smoke-filled longhouses brought on conjunctivities with advancing years; while wounds, dislocations, and fractures were risks in a life on the warpathand the hunt. Possibly asthma and dropsy accompanied advanced age; and the great number of prescriptions for deficiencies of the blood and uterine disorders suggest anemia and complications following childbirth. Zoisberger's description of hardships and disease among the Delaware and Iroquois in the middle eighteenth century is probably typical of earlier times.' [1,297] 'They are subject to festering sores. Cured in one place they break out in another. Chills and fever, dysentery, hemorrhage, and bloody flux in women are very common among them. Venereal diseases having during the last years spread more and more, * * * 17' [1,298] Contagious diseases introduced by Europeans caused several epidemics: 'The latter and possibly tuberculosis were the worst of the imported infectious diseases which included measles, scarlet fever, diphtheria, chicken pox, smallpox, typhus, typhoid, malaria, and yellow fever. Were it not for these introduced contagions, says the Jesuit ethnologist Francois Lafitau, who visited the Caughnawaga Mohawk band and the Abenaki of St. Francis during the second decade of the eighteenth century, and scrofulous maladies caused by hardness of drinking water melted from snow and a kind of phthisis (consumption) contracted by exposing chest and abdomen to winter blasts, for which they had developed no remedy, and which carried a majority to the grave ere the prime of life, their otherwise rigorous constitutions stood them to an extreme old age in which they had either to be knocked on the head or suffered to go out like a light by a mere default of nature.' [1,299] 'Epidemics were terribly destructive to the Native Americans. The epidemics among the Huron in the 1830's and 1840's claimed nearly half of their population. An earlier occurrence among the Gaspesian Micmacs resulted in moral and spiritual degeneration including a loss of faith in their shamans.' [1,300] 'Scholars have not fully appreciated “the panic that seized the communities when faced with what was in their eyes genocide . . . measles, whooping cough, smallpox, influenza, typhoid, diptheria, colds, chicken pox, scarlet fever, tuberculosis, and strep infection . . . quickly took on pandemic proportions.” The shamans of Huronia had to bear most of the burden of stopping the epidemics [Page 21] (J.R. 13:131; 13:175; 13:203; 13:213-215; 13:227-331; 13:235; 13:259-261; 14:9; 14:13; 19:243). This unmanageable situation must have been destructive of Huron and Iroquois shamanic credibility. The Indians' intense concern with health and illness found in the seventeenth century literature was an abnormal state of affairs. Prior to contact, the Indians had not known disease on such a scale. This change should be kept in mind when evaluating the dream-vision material.' [1,301] 'Wallace does not seem to have taken into account to any significant extent, the unique historical and cultural circumstances of the seventeenth century in his psychological profile of the Iroquoians. For example, the Indian's frequent concern over disease and illness is largely due to the epidemics that plagued the Hurons and Iroquois during the seventeenth century. Completely new symptoms frustrated the ability of the traditional health complex to deal both with the diagnosis and treatment of the illness. The widespread and sudden nature of these pandemics undoubtedly taxed the shamans' time and skills and the time and energy required of the community to act out the dreamwishes of the ill persons. One result of this disaster must have been an increased concern for “hidden” or “forgotten” dream-visions that might give further clues to the nature of these disorders. More will be said of this later in the context of its effect on shamanism. The main point is that any conclusions regarding an Iroquois psychological profile and the nature of their dream-vision experiences must take [Page 81] into account not only their cultural system and worldview but also any unusual circumstances that may have affected the texts and other sources that one uses in understanding and interpreting such phenomena.' [1,302] 'The serious epidemic of the winter, 1776-1777, had claimed the lives of many sachems who represented their people on the Iroquois Federal Council and threw the decision-making process into the hands of the warriors and local chiefs. Some of the most prominent leaders of the Nation, such as Red Jacket of the Seneca and Joseph Brant of the Mohawk were not League chiefs, but what has been called “Pine Tree Chiefs” or “merit chiefs.” Since the different factions (pro-Americans; pro-British; pro-neutrality) could not agree at the National level, the council fire of the League was covered over in 1777. Each tribe could pursue its own path.' [1,303] 'The increase in deaths due to epidemics, war and starvation contributed to the vanishing of the traditional shamans of the Iroquoians. The seventeenth and eighteenth centuries also saw the decrease in traditional guardian-spirit quests at puberty and a general decrease in belief in guardian spirits. Medicine societies, on the other hand, were gaining in strength and were under the patronage of a tutelary spirit. They assimilated into their traditions and hence “saved” many of the shamanistic songs, dances and healing techniques. Traditional Iroquoian shamanism was disappearing.' [1,304] 'Fenton holds that the False-Face rituals did not enter the Seneca society until the latter half of the seventeenth century, after the devastating defeat of the Hurons by the Iroquois. It may also be that the Seneca began to use the masks when they were visited by the great epidemics. It is most likely that they were quite aware of the function of these masks from their observation of Huronian practices during the latter's epidemics. Being in the grip of such a powerful, deadly and decimating disease, the Seneca and other [Page 240] Iroquoians would undoubtedly have tried any and all magico-religious devices at hand.' [1,305] 'With rapidly expanding White settlement of Ohio and the passage of President Andrew Jackson's Removal Bill in 1830, both groups of Ohio Iroquois signed treaties in 1831 providing for their removal west of the Mississippi, exchanging their Ohio lands for land in northeastern Indian Territory and for annuity payments. Three men from Sandusky had already searched for new lands in the west on a three-year expedition beginning in 1825 (Wheeler-Voegelin 1959:29). The Sandusky people traveled west by steamboat and overland between November 1831 and July 1832, while the Mixed band of Senecas and Shawnees was removed between September and December 1832. Between 25 and 30 percent died on the way, due to much illness and to bad planning for the winter movements under harsh circumstances. In December 1832 these two emigrant groups agreed to amalgamate and slightly rearrange the lands assigned in Indian Territory that then became the Neosho Reservation, the northern half occupied by the Mixed band and the southern by the Senecas from Sandusky (fig. 2) (Wheeler-Voegelin 1959:44-49; Foreman 1946:67-82; Kappler 1904-1941, 2:383-385).' [1,306] The adoption of captives served to replenish the population: 'Throughout the contact period until the American Revolution the Iroquois maintained their aboriginal corporate structurs. Although disease and warfare such as the Beaver Wars of 1748-1780 and the French and Indian War of 1754 had taken their toll in reducing the Iroquois, they, by adopting captives, replenished their population. Fenton noted: By the end of the seventeenth century the adopted or their offspring outnumbered the Iroquois proper. They became thoroughly acculturated and acted more like the Iroquois than the Iroquois themselves. Chieftenship titles were even conforred on adoptees. The rejuvenating power of the People of the Longhouse amazed everyone who wrote about them. (1971:143)' [1,307] We still need to ascertain when precisely the first epidemics broke out.
♠ Disease outbreaks ♣ present ♥ Fenton describes 'native' endemic diseases: 'The picture that we have developed of Indian medicines during the period of its failure to cope with introduced European diseases leads us to inquire how successfully native herbalists treated indigenous ailments. Early travelers remark that certain diseases then common among Europeans were unobserved among the northeastern American tribes. Among these, gout, gravel, and dropsy were mentioned by Lahontan. On the other hand, ailments growing out of their way of life were more frequent: prolonged fasts followed by feasts and periods of famine induced digestive disturbances; rheumatism, neuralgia, pleurisy, and pneumonia were not uncommon among the Iroquois; and long years of group living in smoke-filled longhouses brought on conjunctivities with advancing years; while wounds, dislocations, and fractures were risks in a life on the warpathand the hunt. Possibly asthma and dropsy accompanied advanced age; and the great number of prescriptions for deficiencies of the blood and uterine disorders suggest anemia and complications following childbirth. Zoisberger's description of hardships and disease among the Delaware and Iroquois in the middle eighteenth century is probably typical of earlier times.' [1,308] 'They are subject to festering sores. Cured in one place they break out in another. Chills and fever, dysentery, hemorrhage, and bloody flux in women are very common among them. Venereal diseases having during the last years spread more and more, * * * 17' [1,309] Contagious diseases introduced by Europeans caused several epidemics: 'The latter and possibly tuberculosis were the worst of the imported infectious diseases which included measles, scarlet fever, diphtheria, chicken pox, smallpox, typhus, typhoid, malaria, and yellow fever. Were it not for these introduced contagions, says the Jesuit ethnologist Francois Lafitau, who visited the Caughnawaga Mohawk band and the Abenaki of St. Francis during the second decade of the eighteenth century, and scrofulous maladies caused by hardness of drinking water melted from snow and a kind of phthisis (consumption) contracted by exposing chest and abdomen to winter blasts, for which they had developed no remedy, and which carried a majority to the grave ere the prime of life, their otherwise rigorous constitutions stood them to an extreme old age in which they had either to be knocked on the head or suffered to go out like a light by a mere default of nature.' [1,310] 'Epidemics were terribly destructive to the Native Americans. The epidemics among the Huron in the 1830's and 1840's claimed nearly half of their population. An earlier occurrence among the Gaspesian Micmacs resulted in moral and spiritual degeneration including a loss of faith in their shamans.' [1,311] 'Scholars have not fully appreciated “the panic that seized the communities when faced with what was in their eyes genocide . . . measles, whooping cough, smallpox, influenza, typhoid, diptheria, colds, chicken pox, scarlet fever, tuberculosis, and strep infection . . . quickly took on pandemic proportions.” The shamans of Huronia had to bear most of the burden of stopping the epidemics [Page 21] (J.R. 13:131; 13:175; 13:203; 13:213-215; 13:227-331; 13:235; 13:259-261; 14:9; 14:13; 19:243). This unmanageable situation must have been destructive of Huron and Iroquois shamanic credibility. The Indians' intense concern with health and illness found in the seventeenth century literature was an abnormal state of affairs. Prior to contact, the Indians had not known disease on such a scale. This change should be kept in mind when evaluating the dream-vision material.' [1,312] 'Wallace does not seem to have taken into account to any significant extent, the unique historical and cultural circumstances of the seventeenth century in his psychological profile of the Iroquoians. For example, the Indian's frequent concern over disease and illness is largely due to the epidemics that plagued the Hurons and Iroquois during the seventeenth century. Completely new symptoms frustrated the ability of the traditional health complex to deal both with the diagnosis and treatment of the illness. The widespread and sudden nature of these pandemics undoubtedly taxed the shamans' time and skills and the time and energy required of the community to act out the dreamwishes of the ill persons. One result of this disaster must have been an increased concern for “hidden” or “forgotten” dream-visions that might give further clues to the nature of these disorders. More will be said of this later in the context of its effect on shamanism. The main point is that any conclusions regarding an Iroquois psychological profile and the nature of their dream-vision experiences must take [Page 81] into account not only their cultural system and worldview but also any unusual circumstances that may have affected the texts and other sources that one uses in understanding and interpreting such phenomena.' [1,313] 'The serious epidemic of the winter, 1776-1777, had claimed the lives of many sachems who represented their people on the Iroquois Federal Council and threw the decision-making process into the hands of the warriors and local chiefs. Some of the most prominent leaders of the Nation, such as Red Jacket of the Seneca and Joseph Brant of the Mohawk were not League chiefs, but what has been called “Pine Tree Chiefs” or “merit chiefs.” Since the different factions (pro-Americans; pro-British; pro-neutrality) could not agree at the National level, the council fire of the League was covered over in 1777. Each tribe could pursue its own path.' [1,314] 'The increase in deaths due to epidemics, war and starvation contributed to the vanishing of the traditional shamans of the Iroquoians. The seventeenth and eighteenth centuries also saw the decrease in traditional guardian-spirit quests at puberty and a general decrease in belief in guardian spirits. Medicine societies, on the other hand, were gaining in strength and were under the patronage of a tutelary spirit. They assimilated into their traditions and hence “saved” many of the shamanistic songs, dances and healing techniques. Traditional Iroquoian shamanism was disappearing.' [1,315] 'Fenton holds that the False-Face rituals did not enter the Seneca society until the latter half of the seventeenth century, after the devastating defeat of the Hurons by the Iroquois. It may also be that the Seneca began to use the masks when they were visited by the great epidemics. It is most likely that they were quite aware of the function of these masks from their observation of Huronian practices during the latter's epidemics. Being in the grip of such a powerful, deadly and decimating disease, the Seneca and other [Page 240] Iroquoians would undoubtedly have tried any and all magico-religious devices at hand.' [1,316] 'With rapidly expanding White settlement of Ohio and the passage of President Andrew Jackson's Removal Bill in 1830, both groups of Ohio Iroquois signed treaties in 1831 providing for their removal west of the Mississippi, exchanging their Ohio lands for land in northeastern Indian Territory and for annuity payments. Three men from Sandusky had already searched for new lands in the west on a three-year expedition beginning in 1825 (Wheeler-Voegelin 1959:29). The Sandusky people traveled west by steamboat and overland between November 1831 and July 1832, while the Mixed band of Senecas and Shawnees was removed between September and December 1832. Between 25 and 30 percent died on the way, due to much illness and to bad planning for the winter movements under harsh circumstances. In December 1832 these two emigrant groups agreed to amalgamate and slightly rearrange the lands assigned in Indian Territory that then became the Neosho Reservation, the northern half occupied by the Mixed band and the southern by the Senecas from Sandusky (fig. 2) (Wheeler-Voegelin 1959:44-49; Foreman 1946:67-82; Kappler 1904-1941, 2:383-385).' [1,317] The adoption of captives served to replenish the population: 'Throughout the contact period until the American Revolution the Iroquois maintained their aboriginal corporate structurs. Although disease and warfare such as the Beaver Wars of 1748-1780 and the French and Indian War of 1754 had taken their toll in reducing the Iroquois, they, by adopting captives, replenished their population. Fenton noted: By the end of the seventeenth century the adopted or their offspring outnumbered the Iroquois proper. They became thoroughly acculturated and acted more like the Iroquois than the Iroquois themselves. Chieftenship titles were even conforred on adoptees. The rejuvenating power of the People of the Longhouse amazed everyone who wrote about them. (1971:143)' [1,318] We still need to ascertain when precisely the first epidemics broke out.
♠ Endemic malnutrition ♣ present ♥ Fenton and Waugh imply that periods of famine occurred on a regular basis: 'The picture that we have developed of Indian medicines during the period of its failure to cope with introduced European diseases leads us to inquire how successfully native herbalists treated indigenous ailments. Early travelers remark that certain diseases then common among Europeans were unobserved among the northeastern American tribes. Among these, gout, gravel, and dropsy were mentioned by Lahontan. On the other hand, ailments growing out of their way of life were more frequent: prolonged fasts followed by feasts and periods of famine induced digestive disturbances; rheumatism, neuralgia, pleurisy, and pneumonia were not uncommon among the Iroquois; and long years of group living in smoke-filled longhouses brought on conjunctivities with advancing years; while wounds, dislocations, and fractures were risks in a life on the warpathand the hunt. Possibly asthma and dropsy accompanied advanced age; and the great number of prescriptions for deficiencies of the blood and uterine disorders suggest anemia and complications following childbirth. Zoisberger's description of hardships and disease among the Delaware and Iroquois in the middle eighteenth century is probably typical of earlier times.' [1,319] 'On some occasions, as a result of over-eating, squashes seem to have been the cause of severe intestinal disturbances. Heckewelder observed “that these fevers break out nearly always in the wild plum season, . . . sometimes, also, after a long famine or deprivation of food; when they eat to excess the green corn, squashes (courges) and other watery vegetables.” Similar references are to be found elsewhere. The Relations note that few died of this complaint.' [1,320]

Physiology

♠ Average height (male) ♣ ♥ We have found no information on height.
♠ Average height (female) ♣ ♥ We have found no information on height.

Prosocial Behavior[edit]

♠ Volunteering ♣ absent ♥

♠ Charity ♣ absent ♥ Mutual aid societies were present on the village level: 'The members of matrisibs cooperated in economic activities and were obligated to avenge the death or injury of any other member. Moieties had reciprocal and complementary ceremonial functions and competed against one another in games. Matrisibs cut across tribal boundaries so that members were found in each tribe and village and often within each longhouse.' [1,321] 'The Iroquois organized various village-wide mutual aid societies. First, a village-wide warrior group cleared the fields and built the palisades (Lafitau, 1724, 2:3). Second, the males had a communal hunt previous to the major festivals. This hunt was supervised by ceremonial officials. Jessie Cornplanter revealed: The communal hunt is entirely of a different nature from the individual hunt. It occurs only when ceremonies, such as Mid-Winter are about to begin. Then the Faith Keepers go, as they say, ‘hunting all abreast’, meaning sert of a drive. (Quain, 1961: 252, fn. 2). Third, a women's mutual aid society gathered in village-wide groups in order to prepare the ground, sew the soil, harvest the produce and gather the wood. Internal order was maintained by older females who supervised the activities of the younger women (Quain, 1961:258). Mary Jamison described some of the activities of the women's aid society: In order to expedite their business and at the same time enjoy each other's company, they all work together in one field or at whatever job they may have at hand. In the spring they chose an old active squaw to be their driver and everseer when at labor, and they consider themselves bound to obey her. When the time for planting arrives and the sail is prepared, the squaws are assembled in the morning and conducted into a field where each plants one row. They then go into the next and plant one acress, and so on until they have gone through the tribe. If any remains to be planted they again commence where they did at first (in the same field) and so keep on until the whole is completed. By this rule they perform their labor of every kind and every jealousy of one having done more or less than another is effectively avoided. (Seaver, 1918: 175). At harvest time the men did not join the women of the mutual aid society in the villagewide effort to harvest the crop. However, men participated in husking (Parker, 1968:31).' [1,322] In addition, allied matrilineages exchanged produce and services: 'Another significant integration was feasting. Lafitau (1724, 2) maintained that the village must threw a feast to entice warriers to clear the fields, and that individuals threw feasts to increase prestige. Feasts occured after calondar rituals, burials, and ceremonies honering the dead. Indeed, the support of the women's aid society was accomplished by a feast after the marriage wood ceremony. Feasting was a redistributive mechanism that cemented productive relations, as well as an integral part of the prestige and belief system, and as such will be examined in a subsequent section. In recapitulation, two complomentary principles deminated Iroquois productive organization; they were alliance and exchange. Within the village economy existed ceremonies which, at crucial times, such as the Mid-winter feast and harvest, united the labor force in accordance with sexual productive roles. At another level of organization, individual matrilineages through marriage alliances established produce and service exchanges in order to increase their productivity.' [1,323] However, this does not seem to constitute 'charity'.

Voluntary Associations

♠ voluntary trade associations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary trade associations ♣ ♥
♠ voluntary community organizations ♣ present ♥ Mutual aid societies were present on the village level: 'The members of matrisibs cooperated in economic activities and were obligated to avenge the death or injury of any other member. Moieties had reciprocal and complementary ceremonial functions and competed against one another in games. Matrisibs cut across tribal boundaries so that members were found in each tribe and village and often within each longhouse.' [1,324] 'The Iroquois organized various village-wide mutual aid societies. First, a village-wide warrior group cleared the fields and built the palisades (Lafitau, 1724, 2:3). Second, the males had a communal hunt previous to the major festivals. This hunt was supervised by ceremonial officials. Jessie Cornplanter revealed: The communal hunt is entirely of a different nature from the individual hunt. It occurs only when ceremonies, such as Mid-Winter are about to begin. Then the Faith Keepers go, as they say, ‘hunting all abreast’, meaning sert of a drive. (Quain, 1961: 252, fn. 2). Third, a women's mutual aid society gathered in village-wide groups in order to prepare the ground, sew the soil, harvest the produce and gather the wood. Internal order was maintained by older females who supervised the activities of the younger women (Quain, 1961:258). Mary Jamison described some of the activities of the women's aid society: In order to expedite their business and at the same time enjoy each other's company, they all work together in one field or at whatever job they may have at hand. In the spring they chose an old active squaw to be their driver and everseer when at labor, and they consider themselves bound to obey her. When the time for planting arrives and the sail is prepared, the squaws are assembled in the morning and conducted into a field where each plants one row. They then go into the next and plant one acress, and so on until they have gone through the tribe. If any remains to be planted they again commence where they did at first (in the same field) and so keep on until the whole is completed. By this rule they perform their labor of every kind and every jealousy of one having done more or less than another is effectively avoided. (Seaver, 1918: 175). At harvest time the men did not join the women of the mutual aid society in the villagewide effort to harvest the crop. However, men participated in husking (Parker, 1968:31).' [1,325] In addition, allied matrilineages exchanged produce and services: 'Another significant integration was feasting. Lafitau (1724, 2) maintained that the village must threw a feast to entice warriers to clear the fields, and that individuals threw feasts to increase prestige. Feasts occured after calondar rituals, burials, and ceremonies honering the dead. Indeed, the support of the women's aid society was accomplished by a feast after the marriage wood ceremony. Feasting was a redistributive mechanism that cemented productive relations, as well as an integral part of the prestige and belief system, and as such will be examined in a subsequent section. In recapitulation, two complomentary principles deminated Iroquois productive organization; they were alliance and exchange. Within the village economy existed ceremonies which, at crucial times, such as the Mid-winter feast and harvest, united the labor force in accordance with sexual productive roles. At another level of organization, individual matrilineages through marriage alliances established produce and service exchanges in order to increase their productivity.' [1,326]
♠ prestige of voluntary community organizations ♣ ♥ As Iroquois was not divided into social classes per se, this variable may not be applicable here.
♠ voluntary athletic clubs ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of voluntary athletic clubs organizations ♣ ♥
♠ other voluntary organizations ♣ absent ♥
♠ prestige of other voluntary organizations ♣ ♥
♠ voluntary religious associations ♣ present ♥ 'Illness and disease were attributed to supernatural causes. Curing ceremonies consisted of group shamanistic practices directed towards propitiating the responsible supernatural agents. One of the curing groups was the False Face Society. False Face Societies were found in each village and, except for a female Keeper of the False Faces who protected the ritual paraphernalia, consisted only of male members who had dreamed of participation in False Face ceremonies.' [1,327] 'Witchcraft was the most serious type of anti-social behavior. The Iroquois believed that witches, in concert with the Evil Spirit, could cause disease, accident, death, or other misfortune. Because witches were thought to be able to transform themselves into other objects, they were difficult to catch and punish.' [1,328] There were multiple shamanistic healing societies: 'As it has been previoualy stated, the curing societies integrate the four longhouses because members from the four longhouses participate in the nuxerous curing societies. Curing rituals also figure proainently in the ealendric cycle. Each society cures a specific illness. Speck (1949) lists the specialties of the various curing societies: Bear Society Rite: relief from howling hysteria and attacts of dementia in which the victim ‘crawls on the ground in the manner of a bear’...Otter Society Rite: relief from nervous tremors and associated afflictions (not demontia)...White Buffale Society Dance: relief from demontia, convulsions, bellewing hysteria...Wooden False Face Society Rite: relief from hemorrages of the nose, facial paralysis, mouth drawn to one side, dream persecution by visions, and annoyance by False Face spirits and frights in the bush...Corn-Huak Mask Society Rite: relief from afflicting dreams or hallucinations. Medicine Men's (Big Rattle) Society Rite and the Pig Mask Rite: cures bodily injury, wounds and incurable diseases and immunises against the coming of sickness foretold by a dream or vision. [Page 243] Little Water, or Dark Dance, Society Rite: relief from general sickness, called for when a person has a vision of the dwarf spirits. Eagle Society Dance Rite: relief from nervous debility (St. Vitus's dance). (1949:59-60.)' [1,329] While some forms of shamanism declined in the 17th and 18th centuries, healing societies were resilient: 'The increase in deaths due to epidemics, war and starvation contributed to the vanishing of the traditional shamans of the Iroquoians. The seventeenth and eighteenth centuries also saw the decrease in traditional guardian-spirit quests at puberty and a general decrease in belief in guardian spirits. Medicine societies, on the other hand, were gaining in strength and were under the patronage of a tutelary spirit. They assimilated into their traditions and hence “saved” many of the shamanistic songs, dances and healing techniques. Traditional Iroquoian shamanism was disappearing.' [1,330] 'A person joins a society when he or she dreams of the masks or of the rituals or when a clairvoyant prescribes the ceremony as a curing agent. Sometimes the disease symptoms by their very nature lead an individual or fortuneteller to conclude that somehow it was “caused” by a particular society and can only be cured by them. Such is the numinous quality of False-Face power, i.e., it works ill and well. Usual symptoms of illness are “ailments of the head, shoulders and joints. They cause and cure swelling of the face, toothache, inflammation of the eyes, nose bleeding, sore chin and earache. At Tonawanda, red spots on the patient's face calls for the red Faces, [Page 236] who should dance before sunrise. Black spots require the use of black masks at night.”' [1,331] The False Face society is particularly prominent in the ethnography: 'The prime motive in the establishment of this organization was to propitiate those demons called Falsefaces, and among other good results to arrest pestilence and disease. In course of time the band itself was believed to have a species of control over diseases, and over the healing art; and they were often invoked for the cure of simple diseases, and to drive away, or exorcise the plague, if it had actually broken out in their midst. As recently as the summer of 1849, when the cholera prevailed through the State, the Falsefaces, in appropriate costume, went from house to house at Tonawanda, through the old school portion of the village, and performed the usual ceremonies prescribed for the expulsion of the pestilence.//'When any one was sick with a complaint within the range of their healing powers, and dreamed that he saw a Falseface, this was interpreted to signify that through their instrumentality he was to be cured. Having informed the mistress of the band, and prepared the customary feast, the Falsefaces at once appeared, preceded by their female leader, and marching in Indian file. Each one wore a mask or false face, a tattered blanket over his shoulders, and carried a turtle shell rattle in his hand. On entering the house of the invalid they first stirred the ashes upon the hearth, and then sprinkled the patient over with hot ashes until his head and hair were covered; after which they performed some manipulations over him in turn, and finally led him around with them in the falseface dance ( Gä-go-s[unknown] ), with which their ceremonies concluded. When these performances were over, the entertainment prepared for the occasion was distributed to the band, and by [Page 160] them carried away for their private feasting, as they never unmasked themselves before the people. Among the simple complaints which the Falsefaces could cure infallibly, were nose bleed, toothache, swellings, and inflammation of the eyes. The false face shown in the figure was purchased of an Onondaga on Grand river.' [1,332] 'Fenton holds that the False-Face rituals did not enter the Seneca society until the latter half of the seventeenth century, after the devastating defeat of the Hurons by the Iroquois. It may also be that the Seneca began to use the masks when they were visited by the great epidemics. It is most likely that they were quite aware of the function of these masks from their observation of Huronian practices during the latter's epidemics. Being in the grip of such a powerful, deadly and decimating disease, the Seneca and other [Page 240] Iroquoians would undoubtedly have tried any and all magico-religious devices at hand.' [1,333]
♠ prestige of voluntary religious associations ♣ ♥ As Iroquois was not divided into social classes per se, this variable may not be applicable here.

Economy variables (polity-level)[edit]

State Income[edit]

♠ Tribute ♣ present ♥ The league received tribute from subject peoples: 'Up to 1693 the Iroquois also used wampum as money, either in strings or loose. It served as currency between the Indians and the Dutch and English colonists. Enormous quantities were used to pay the tribute demanded from the Iroquois by other Indian tribes.' [1,334] 'Hale (1965:88-89) has summarized the principles and methods used by the Iroquois in attempting to establish universal peace. The League's primary goal was the voluntary admittance of all nations and tribes. However admirable this project was, the realities of life quickly demonstrated a great void between ideology and execution. Nevertheless, some [Page 52] Nanticokes, Tuteloes, a band of Delawares, and the Tuscarora were ultimately admitted to the League. If a nation did not ask outright to join the League, the Iroquois then sought to accomplish the same end by suggesting a treaty of alliance. Should subtle hints of this nature fail to bring the desired response the third alternative was to declare war. If the unfortunate nation capitulated early, it was at once spared and usually allowed to retain its territory and most of its property. The people were required to acknowledge the Iroquois as their superior, to pay a modest tribute in wampum and furs, and refrain from any further war activity. When all else failed, the Iroquois did not hesitate to totally annihilate whole tribes. “But,” Hale (1965:95) points out, the Iroquois never for a moment forgot the principles which lay at the foundation of their League, and which taught them to “strengthen their house” by converting enemies into friends. On the instant that resistance ceased, slaughter ceased with it. The warriors who were willing to unite their fortunes with the Confederates were at once welcomed among them. Some were adopted into the families of those who had lost children or brothers. Others had lands allotted to them, on which they were allowed to live by themselves, under their own chiefs and their native laws, until in two or three generations, by friendly intercourse, frequent intermarriages, and community of interests, they became gradually absorbed into the society about them.' [1,335] 'If we examine the conditions under which European-Iroquois contacts took place it may be possible to suggest the factors which were responsible for the League's losing its independent status. At the outset we can dismiss the consideration that the League may have failed to comprehend fully the significance of sovereignty. As a confederate body to which member nations had delegated control of external affairs, the League was practiced in dealing with self-governing Indian groups. As conquerors of many neighboring tribes from which they collected tribute they inevitably learned the distinction between an independent and a subject people. The English were assisted in their relations with Amerind groups by possessing an apperceptive background for contact which the Iroquois lacked. Earlier voyages had acquainted them with the existence of other races and cultures and provided an opportunity for appraising their position in relation to other societies. The Six Nations, not possessing this experience, were relatively unprepared for the appearance of Europeans.' [1,336] The Delaware paid tribute to the league: 'In 1712, when the Delaware got ready to carry their annual tribute to Onondaga, they sent for the Governor of Pennsylvania and laid out on the floor 32 belts of wampum in which various figures had been wrought by their women, and a large calumet which they said had been given to them a generation previously when they submitted to the Five Nations, who had told them to show it whenever they came to a new place and on returning to Onondaga as symbolic of their friendship and subjection to the Five Nations. The calumet, which attracted some attention and is variously described in the records, had “a stone head, a wooden or cane shaft, and feathers fixt to it like wings, with other ornaments” (Provincial Council of Pa., Minutes, 1852, vol. 2, p. 546; Hanna, 1911, vol. 1, pp. 101-102 [slightly different]; Weslager, 1944, p. 383).' [1,337] It seems the Mohawk also collected tribute independently of the league: 'The Mohawks were receivers of tribute from subjugated nations. This hereditary privilege must be placed upon the same footing with the preceding. It may, perhaps, indicate that the nations upon their borders were in subjection.' [1,338] 'Theoretically, the tribes of the Confederacy enjoyed equality within the structure of the League. The special prerogatives held by certain tribes were the result of accidents of location, and numerical differences in the tribes at the time of the formation of the Confederacy. The four (or three) brothers side or moiety were elder brothers of the three (or two) brothers moiety. The Mohawk of the elder brother side were referred to or, as it may be rendered, the shield.” The special prerogative of this tribe was the right to collect tribute from subject tribes. The Seneca, also of this moiety, were the guardians of the “western door” because of their geographical position along the western boundary of the Confederacy, and were known as those “who threw out the snake.” That is, it was their duty to dispose of any matters harmful to the League. In addition to this [Page 39] privilege, the Seneca were further honored by being assigned the two hereditary war chiefships of the League. The most important honors belonged to the third tribe of this moiety, the Onondaga. They were the Firekeeepers of the Confederacy and one of their chiefs was the custodian of the Council wampum. No particular prerogatives belonged to the two tribes of the younger brother moiety; the Oneida who were known as the Great Tree, and the Cayuga whose national epithet was the Great Pipe.' [1,339]

♠ Staple ♣ absent ♥ eHRAF provides a general summary of Iroquois political and military history: 'The Iroquoian confederacy was organized sometime between 1400 and A.D. 1600 for the purpose of maintaining peaceful relations between the 5 constituent tribes. Subsequent to European contact relations within the confederacy were sometimes strained as each of the 5 tribes sought to expand and maintain its own interests in the developing fur trade. For the most part, however, the fur trade served to strengthen the confederacy because tribal interests often complemented one another and all gained from acting in concert. The League was skillful at playing French and English interests off against one another to its advantage and thereby was able to play a major role in the economic and political events of northeastern North America during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The Iroquois aggressively maintained and expanded their role in the fur trade and as a result periodically found themselves at war with their neighbors, such as the Huron, Petun, and the Neutral to the West and the Susquehannock to the south. Much of the fighting was done by the Seneca, the most powerful of the Iroquoian tribes. From 1667 to the 1680s the Iroquois maintained friendly relations with the French and during this time Jesuit missions were established among each of the 5 tribes.' [1,340] 'However, Iroquois aggression and expansion eventually brought them into conflict with the French and, at the same time, into closer alliance with the English. In 1687, 1693 and 1696 French military expeditions raided and burned Iroquois villages and fields. During Queen Anne's War (1702-1713) the Iroquois allied with the English and at the War's end were acknowledged to be British subjects, though they continued to aggressively maintain and extend their middleman role between English traders at Fort Orange (Albany) and native groups farther west. The victory of the English over the French in North America in 1763 weakened the power of the confederacy by undermining the strategic economic and political position of the tribes and by promoting the rapid expansion of White settlement. When the American Revolution broke out in 1775 neither the League as a whole nor even the tribes individually were able to agree on a common course of action. Most of the Iroquois allied with the British and as a result during and after the Revolution were forced from their homelands. In the period following the American Revolution the members of the Iroquois tribes settled on reservations in western New York state, southern Quebec and southern Ontario, where many of their descendants remain today.' [1,341]
♠ Labor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Currency ♣ present ♥ The above material implies that tribute was paid in wampum beads, i.e. tokens, and furs. In the absence of a more appropriate variable in the codebook, we have coded these under 'currency' for now. Modifications may be needed.

Debt and Indemnities

♠ Polity has obligation to other polity or group ♣ absent ♥
♠ Polity receives obligatory payment from other polity or group ♣ present ♥ See above.

Taxation[edit]

♠ Degree of taxation ♣ absent ♥ There was no taxation within the league: 'Thus the League of the Iroquois was an alliance conceived among aboriginal nations which, though culturally related and speaking languages fundamentally similar but differing in vocabulary and [Page 37] idiom, had recurrently been in conflict. The league brought them out of conflict into peace. Then came the French, the Dutch, and the English, and the doom of the league was sealed, its desired results nullified. Here was an alliance binding together five distinct nations, based upon an orally transmitted constitution. It had no inscribed statutes, no taxes or levies, no gendarmerie, no hireling politicians. We hear, however, of tribute exacted of subjugated tribes. Tribute, as the Iroquois took it, consisted of stipulated sums of wampum demanded of the Algonkian tribes on the Atlantic Coast who produced it; and wampum was not an item of money, cash, or currency in native economy before the coming of Europeans to the Hudson Valley. Its function was that of a symbol, valuable in a spiritual sense and capable of serving the purposes of mnemonic record making. Thus the wampum tribute we read so much about would seem to be a measure pressed upon subjugated smaller tribes in the shell-bearing coastal regions, requiring them to furnish the wampum the Iroquois needed in the score of ceremonial uses they had developed for it.' [1,342]

Taxes are imposed on:

♠ Land ♣ absent ♥
♠ Property ♣ absent ♥
♠ People ♣ absent ♥
♠ Trade ♣ absent ♥
♠ Income ♣ absent ♥
♠ Production ♣ absent ♥

Taxes are imposed by:

♠ executive or ruling elite ♣ absent ♥
♠ local elites ♣ absent ♥
♠ state officials ♣ absent ♥

Type of taxes paid:

♠ Staple ♣ absent ♥
♠ Labor ♣ absent ♥
♠ Currency ♣ absent ♥

Wages and Costs[edit]

♠ Wages ♣ ♥ Note: 'Traditionally, the Iroquois were farmers and hunters who practiced a slash-and-burn form of horticulture. In addition, they fished and gathered berries, plants, and roots. Before the arrival of Europeans the primary weapons were bows and arrows, stone axes and knives and blowguns, however, by the late seventeenth century European trade goods had almost completely replaced the traditional weapons and tools. The principal crops were maize, beans, and squash which, in addition, were prominent in ceremonial activities. In good years surplus crops were dried and stored for future use. After the harvest of crops in the late summer, the seasonal round included fall hunting that lasted until the winter solstice, early spring fishing and hunting of passenger pigeons, and then spring and summer clearing and planting of fields.' [1,343] Labour was divided according to age and gender: 'Traditionally, men hunted and fished, built houses, cleared fields for planting, and were responsible for trade and warfare. In addition, men had the more visible roles in tribal and confederacy politics. Farming was the responsibility of women, whose work also included gathering wild foods, rearing children, preparing food, and making clothing and baskets and other utensils.' [1,344] 'Economically, the maintenance of the household was a joint undertaking, but the women had the chief responsibility in the care of the fields and the raising of the staple foods. Men and women cooperated in the clearing of new fields, after that the women's group took over. Men's hunting added an important relish to the diet. A good meatprovider was considered the best husband. But hunting was more a prestige and recreation point, than a necessity. Village sites were changed when the fields near them were exhausted--every 15 or 20 years with this type of horticulture--rather than when the district had been hunted out. Conflicts with pioneers occurred more often over the decimation of the game animals, due to the clearing and planting of large numbers of acres, rather than over the scarcity of arable land. But in this case one must remember that it was the Iroquois men with their developed war patterns who came in contact with the pioneers.' [1,345] Many goods were produced in the community: 'The Iroquois knew how to bend and shape wood when green or after steaming. House frames, pack frames, snowshoes, toboggans, basket rims, lacrosse sticks and other wood products were made using these techniques. Rope was made from the inner bark of hickory, basswood and slippery elm and burden straps and prisoner ties were made from the braided fibers of nettle, milkweed and hemp. Pipes of fired clay were among the many types of items manufactured by the Iroquois. The Iroquois are known for making ash and maple splint baskets, although this craft may be of European origin.' [1,346] But trade was also important: 'Long before European contact the Iroquois were involved in an intricate trade network with other native groups (see cultural relations above). Clay pipes were an important trade item that reached other native groups all along the east coast of North America. The aggressive behavior the Iroquois exhibited towards their neighbors during the fur trade period has been interpreted by some as the result of their aim to protect and expand their middleman role. Others have suggested that the aggressive behavior of the Iroquois tribes was related to the scarcity of furs in their own territory and the resulting difficulty in obtaining European trade goods. According to this theory, the Iroquois warred primarily to obtain the trade goods of their neighbors in closer contact with Europeans. After the center of fur trading activities had moved farther west, the Iroquois continued to play an important role as voyageurs and trappers.' [1,347] Accordingly, some of the below variables may not be applicable to the Iroquois.

♠ staple cost of principal source of carbohydrates ♣ ♥

♠ Top fortune ♣ ♥

♠ Other wealth distribution ♣ ♥
